questions.text: In a routine radiographic examination of the ankle joint of a 45-year-old patient, an incidental discovery is observed in the X-ray image as shown below. What is this finding?
questions.solution:
The marked area in the X-ray is Os trigonum which is an accessory bone seen behind the talus.

Accessory bones, also known as supernumerary bones are not always present. They may arise due to ununited epiphysis developed from extra ossification centres. Clinically, they may be mistaken for fractures. 

Examples of accessory bones:

  • Os trigonum:  Uncommon accessory bone seen behind the talus. Also known as lateral tubercle of the talus
  • Os vesalianum: Uncommon accessory bone located proximal to the fifth metatarsal and found within the peroneus brevis tendon, also known as tuberosity of the fifth metatarsal.

Other options:

Option C: Fabella is a sesamoid bone. It is found within the tendon of the lateral head of gastrocnemius, where it moves over the lateral femoral condyle. Radiological mage of fabella is given below.

Option D: Rider's bone is an example of heterotopic calcification involving the Adductor longus muscle.

questions.text: The process of apolipoprotein B48 synthesis involves which of the following?
questions.solution:
The production of apolipoprotein (apo) B-48 in the intestine and apoB-100 in the liver is a result of RNA editing.
 
RNA editing is the process by which the coding sequence of the mRNA is changed before translation. As a result, the mRNA template differs from the DNA from which it was transcribed. This leads to the formation of a different protein. This occurs by insertion of additional uracils at the 3’ end of the mRNA and proceeds in 3’ to 5’ direction.
 
RNA editing in apoB synthesis: 
 
The ApoB gene is transcribed into an mRNA that leads to the synthesis of 100 kDa protein in the liver, which is called apoB100.
 
In the intestine, the same primary transcript is formed, but a cytidine deaminase converts a CAA codon in the mRNA into a UAA codon; thus codon for glutamine is changed to a termination codon. Thus 49kDa protein has resulted; this is apoB48.

Other options:

Option a: Transcription is a first step in gene expression. It involves copying a gene's DNA sequence to make an RNA molecule. It is performed by enzymes called RNA polymerases, which link nucleotides to form an RNA strand(using DNA strand as template). It has 3 stages- Initiation, Elongation and Termination.

Option c: Alternative splicing is a form of gene regulation which can produce a variety of protein products from a single hnRNA (heterogeneous nuclear RNA/primary transcript). Suppose there are exons 1, 2,3 and 4. The splicing can be 1-2, 1-3, 1-4, 2-4, 2-3 etc. This leads to the formation of many variants of a protein from a single hnRNA. Alternative splicing has been identified in the case of at least 40 different genes. The calcitonin gene yields an RNA that synthesizes both calcitonin(in the thyroid) or calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP, in the brain). It is also responsible for the different types of Tropomyosin variants in muscle.

Option d: RNA interference is a process by which micro RNAs target the untranslated region in the 3' end after transcription to enable degradation. Different isoforms forming from a single canonical protein cannot be explained by this phenomenon.

questions.text: A gardener from the sub-Himalayan region presents with the multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along the lymphatics. The tissue biopsy was done and sent to the laboratory for culture. On microscopy, the flower-like clusters of conidia as shown in the image below are seen. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is _____
questions.solution:
The presence of multiple vesicles on hand and multiple eruptions along lymphatics in a gardener from the sub-Himalayan region and the microscopic finding of flower-like clusters of conidia are suggestive of sporotrichosis. The most common fungus responsible for this condition is Sporothrix schenckii.

Sporothrix schenckii causes sporotrichosis, a chronic granulomatous disease, by traumatic inoculation into the skin. This is a chronic infection involving cutaneous, subcutaneous, and lymphatic tissue. It usually follows spreads along the draining lymphatics and lymph nodes.

The initial infection develops as a nodule, which may break down to form a necrotic or ulcerative lesion. Untreated, the disease progresses and new nodules develop along the lymphatics leading to a chain of nodules.

Less commonly it may also cause systemic infection following inhalation, which causes local pulmonary disease or may lead to widely disseminated lesions in joints, meninges, and skin.

Laboratory diagnosis includes direct microscopic examination of necrotic material in KOH mount or histopathological examination of tissue sections stained by methenamine silver stain showing the asteroid body. Asteroid body is a rounded or oval, basophilic, yeast-like body 3-5 μmin diameter, with rays of an eosinophilic substance radiating from the yeast cell.

Treatment: Itraconazole is the drug of choice for lymphocutaneous sporotrichosis.

questions.text: Regarding respiratory adjustment seen during exercise, which of the following statements is true?

choices.text: Activity of joint proprioceptors is important factor in increasing ventilation
Arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration remains constant

questions.solution:
Signals from joint proprioceptors play a role in stimulating the respiratory drive during exercise.

Regulation of respiration in exercise

  • During strenuous exercise, O2 consumption and CO2 for­mation can increase as much as 20-fold. Yet in the healthy athlete, the arterial PO2, PCO2, and pH remain almost exactly normal. This is because the alveolar ventilation increases along with the increased level of oxygen metabolism.
  • Part of this stimulation of alveolar ventilation results from direct stimulation of the respiratory center by nervous signals. An additional part is believed to result from sensory signals transmitted into the respiratory center from the contracting muscles and joint proprioceptors.
  • During strenuous exercise, the utilization of O2 in the entire body can increase to 75% to 85%. So, essentially all the oxygen is given to the exercising muscles leading to an increased arterio-venous difference in oxygen concentration.

questions.text: A worried mother brings her 2-year-old child and complains that he has not begun walking or talking. On examination, there is microcephaly, fair hair, light-colored skin, and blue eyes. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a 2 year old child with poor development of milestones and feautures like microcephaly, light hair and skin, points to the diagnosis of Phenylketonuria (PKU).  

Phenylketonuria (PKU) is an inborn error of metabolism seen due to a defect in the enzyme phenylalanine hydroxylase (classic phenylketonuria) and less commonly, due to a defect in BH4 synthase (non-classical). These defects result in the impaired conversion of phenylalanine to tyrosine. The patient develops clinical features due to elevated levels of phenylalanine metabolites and decreased levels of tyrosine. The excess phenylalanine in the blood is metabolized to phenylpyruvate (positive ferric chloride) and phenylacetate (mousy odour) which are excreted in the urine. Infants appear normal at birth and gradually develop symptoms of hyperreflexia, seizures, hypopigmentation, low IQ, hyperactivity, and tremors.

Characteristic clinical findings in Phenylketonuria:

  • Mental retardation
  • Failure to walk or talk
  • Seizures
  • Hyperactivity
  • Tremor
  • Microcephaly
  • Failure to grow
  • Deficiency of pigmentation (fair hair, light skin color, and blue eyes)

Management phenylketonuria include:

Guthrie test is a screening test that shows with absence of growth of Bacillus subtilis.

Tandem mass spectroscopy is the investigation of choice.

The ferric chloride test is positive with the development of a transient blue-green colour.

A diet low in phenylalanine and supplementation of tyrosine can prevent the mental retardation of PKU.  They should avoid aspartame which is an artificial sweetener containing phenylalanine. Sucralose is an artificial sweetener that is safe to use in PKU as it does not contain phenylalanine (Option D)

Other options:

Option A: Oculocutaneous albinism (OCA) is a group of inherited disorders characterized by a reduction or complete lack of melanin pigment in the skin, hair, and eyes. Symptoms include albinism with vision problems like strabismus, photophobia, nystagmus, impaired vision/blindness or astigmatism. Neuropsychiatric manifestations are not seen.

Option C: Alkaptunuria is an inborn error of metabolism due to the deficiency of an enzyme homogentisate oxidase, leading to the accumulation of homogentisic acid in connective tissue resulting in ochronosis. Due to the oxidation and polymerization of homogenetic acid, it shows a characteristic blackening of urine on standing for a long time or black stain in diapers. They often present in the third to the fourth decade of life. 

Option D: Type I tyrosinemia is caused by a deficiency of the enzyme fumarylacetoacetate hydrolase. Children present with mild mental retardation, liver failure, and hypoglycemia. Urine typically has a boiled cabbage odour. Boiled cabbage odour can also be found in cases of hypermethioninemia.

questions.text: A 10-month-old infant was brought with complaints of jerking movements of limbs towards the body. During the attack, the baby typically attains complete heaving of the head forward towards the knees, and then immediately relaxes into the upright position. On examination, there is a regression in developmental milestones. What would be the EEG finding in this case?

choices.text: 1.5-2.5 Hz spike and polyspike bursts in sleep

questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of West syndrome. The EEG in this child would show hypsarrhythmia.

West syndrome is severe generalized epilepsy that begins between the ages of 2 and 12 months. It is characterized by a triad of: 

  1. Infantile epileptic spasms
  2. Developmental regression
  3. Hypsarrhythmia on electroencephalogram (EEG)

Hypsarrhythmia refers to a high voltage, slow, chaotic background with multifocal spikes as shown below.

West syndrome has been known by many names like infantile spasms, salaam attacks, salaam convulsions infantile spastic epilepsy, and jackknife convulsion syndrome. During an attack babies typically attain complete heaving of the head forward towards their knees, and then immediately relax into the upright position.

The image given below illustrates infantile spasms in a child.

Diagnosis is confirmed by EEG which typically shows hypsarrythmia.

The treatment of choice in West syndrome is either adreno-corticotropic hormone (ACTH) or corticosteroids. An antiseizure medication, mainly vigabatrin can be used when associated with tuberous sclerosis.

questions.text:
Match the following metabolic derangements with the most likely enzyme deficient.
  Metabolic derangement   Enzyme deficient
A. Von Gierke disease  1. Glucocerebrosidase deficiency
B. Krabbe's disease 2. Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency
C. Hurler syndrome 3. Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency
D. classical galactosemia 4. Beta-galactosidase deficiency
    5. Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase
questions.solution:
The correct match is A-3, B-4, C-2, and D-5.

A.Von Gierke disease is associated with Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency, it is a glycogen storage disorder (Type Ia). Patients with GSD Type I present with a protruding abdomen due to hepatomegaly, doll-like facies, hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hyperuricemia, organomegaly, seizures, and pulmonary hypertension. It is an autosomal recessive disorder 

B. Krabbe's disease is associated with Beta-galactosidase (Galactocerebrosidase) deficiency, it is a lysosomal storage disorder.The classic manifestations that would suggest Krabbe's disease include irritability, seizures, and hypertonia. Optic atrophy and developmental delay are other features. It is an autosomal recessive disorder.

C. Hurler syndrome is associated with Alpha-L-iduronidase deficiency,  a type of mucopolysaccharidosis type I. Infants develop characteristic coarse facial features, hepatosplenomegaly, inguinal hernias, and typical skeletal abnormalities, known as dysostosis multiplex. Corneal clouding, short stature, and copious nasal discharge are other features.

D. Classical galactosemia is associated with Galactose-1-phosphate uridyl transferase deficiency. Clinical features include jaundice, vomiting, hepatomegaly, and sepsis. They also tend to develop cataracts.

Glucocerebrosidase deficiency is associated with Gaucher's disease. It is the most common lysosomal storage disorder. Presents with hepatosplenomegaly, pancytopenia, osteoporosis, avascular necrosis of the femur, and bone crises. Gaucher cells are lipid-laden macrophages resembling crumpled tissue paper.

questions.text: A primi presented to the hospital in active labor and was found to be HIV positive. She is not on any antiretroviral therapy. According to the NACO guidelines, what is the minimum prophylactic antiretroviral therapy to be started in the neonate after birth?
questions.solution:
A baby born to an HIV-positive mother who is not on ART is classified as a high-risk infant. The recommended minimum ARV prophylaxis is syrup nevirapine + syrup zidovudine from birth to 6 weeks. For exclusively breastfed infants, this is extended till 12 weeks.

According to the National AIDS Control Organization (NACO), antiretroviral therapy (ART) should be given to all pregnant women, including during labor hours and breastfeeding. They are started on a triple-drug ART. ART should be given irrespective of the CD4 count, and clinical stage and should be continued lifelong.

Exclusive breastfeeding (EBF) is recommended for all HIV-exposed infants. At 6 months of age, these infants should be offered complementary foods along with breast milk.

Infants should receive ARV prophylaxis. A single drug or dual drug regimen is followed depending on the risk of transmission which can be low or high risk.

  • Low-risk infants are those born to mothers with a low viral load which is detected after 32 weeks of pregnancy till delivery. 
  • High-risk infants are those born to HIV-positive mothers, not on ART, with viral load not estimated beyond 32 weeks, maternal viral load not suppressed after 32 weeks, or mothers newly diagnosed with HIV within 6 weeks of delivery.

questions.text: A 15-year-old boy presents with swelling in the upper diaphyseal part of the tibia. X-ray of the swelling showed a periosteal reaction. A histopathological image of the biopsy is given below. Immunohistochemistry was positive for synaptophysin and mic 2. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with the image showing small round blue cells and immunohistochemistry (IHC) positive for synaptophysin and mic-2 point to a likely diagnosis of Ewing sarcoma. 

Ewing sarcoma is the 2nd most common bone sarcoma in children. The majority of the patients affected are usually <20 years of age. It has a slight male predominance. 

It commonly involves the diaphysis of the long bones like the femur, tibia, fibula, and humerus and flat bones of the pelvis. The majority of Ewing sarcomas have t(11:22). 

Patients present with painful enlarging mass, fever, and anaemia. The affected area is usually tender, swollen, and warm. Laboratory findings may show an elevated WBC count and erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR). 

A histopathological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows sheets of uniform, round cells arranged in Homer-Wright rosettes. These cells are of neuroectodermal origin and have minimal cytoplasm and abundant glycogen. When they are arranged around a central fibrillary core in the form of clusters, the appearance is termed Homer-Wright rosettes. Immunohistochemistry is usually positive for synaptophysin and mic-2.

Given below is the histopathological appearance of Ewing sarcoma. 

As tumor cells are rich in glycogen, they stain positive for periodic acid Schiff (PAS) stain however, they stain negatively for reticulin.

Radiological examination of Ewing sarcoma shows a destructive lesion in the diaphysis of long bones. Deposition of periosteal reaction in layers gives an onion-peel appearance (shown below). 

Other options:

Option A: Osteosarcoma is the most common primary malignancy of bone. The histological features of osteosarcoma include pleomorphic cells with hyperchromatic nuclei and abundant mitoses. The diagnosis is definitive with the presence of malignant tumor cells producing unmineralized osteoid or mineralized bone arranged in a typically fine, lacelike pattern.

X-ray shows periosteal reaction and it may take the form of a Codman's triangle or it may have a sunray appearance as shown below.

Option C: Neuroblastoma is a tumor of the sympathetic ganglia and adrenal medulla. It is derived from primordial neural crest cells. It is the most common extracranial solid tumor in childhood. On histopathology, small round blue cells are seen. These cells are concentrically arranged around a faintly eosinophilic fibrillary material (neuropil). This appearance is called Homer-Wright pseudorosettes

Option D: Osteoclastoma is also known as a giant cell tumour. The tumor cells are primitive osteoblast precursors and express high levels of RANKL. Histologically, the tumors consist of osteoclast-type giant cells with 100 or more nuclei. These cells are usually present against a backdrop of mononuclear stromal cells as shown below.

The image below shows an X-ray of a giant cell tumour showing the typical soap bubble appearance.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented after an episode of acute gastroenteritis and was infused with fluids. A while later, after fluid infusion, his heart rate rose to 122 bpm and he complained of palpitations. The presence of tachycardia can be explained by which of the following mechanisms?
questions.solution:
The presence of tachycardia can be explained by the Bainbridge reflex.

It is a compensatory cardiac reflex where there is an increase in the heart rate in response to raised atrial stretch.

In fluid overload states, commonly after excessive fluid infusion, there is distension of the atria due to increased blood volume. This distension activates the atrial stretch receptors which transmit the afferent signals to the medulla via the vagus nerve. The efferent signals are then transmitted back through vagal and sympathetic nerves. This leads to an increase in the strength of contraction of the heart and tachycardia. This reflex helps in preventing excess accumulation of blood in the atria, veins, and in the pulmonary circulation.

Other options - 

Option A: Bezold-Jarisch reflex is due to the activation of chemosensitive vagal C fibers in the cardiopulmonary region. They can be elicited after administering certain irritants like capsaicin or serotonin. It can also be activated during myocardial infarction and on exposure to radioactive dyes during coronary angiography. This reflex is characterized by profound brady­cardia, hypotension, and a brief period of apnea followed by rapid shallow breathing. 

Option B: Pulmonary chemoreflex is due to the stimulation of the J-receptors (C receptors/juxta-pulmonary capillary receptors) which are stimulated when there is hyperinflation of the lung. This produces reflex apnea followed by a rapid increase in breathing rate, bradycardia, and hypotension.

Option D: Cushing's reflex is seen when the intracranial pressure is raised where the blood supply to ventrolateral medulla neurons is compromised. The local hypoxia and hypercapnia stimulate the neurons producing hypertension, bradycardia, and irregular respiration.

*Note: Bainbridge reflex causes tachycardia, whereas all the other mentioned reflexes predominately cause bradycardia.

Clinical features include chronic dysentery, anemia, poor growth and developmental defects.

Fecal smears showing barrel-shaped ovum of T. trichura. The eggs of Trichuris trichura does not have a terminal spine. They are barrel-shaped and have mucus plugs at both ends.

questions.text: A patient died of a heart attack a few hours back. On autopsy, it was determined that he is at the stage of cellular death. Which of the following signs can be noted?
questions.solution:
Suggilation/postmortem hypostasis is an early sign of death. Putrefaction, adipocere formation, mummification are late signs of death. 

Immediate signs of death (somatic death):

  • Insensibility and loss of voluntary power
  • Cessation of respiration
  • Cessation of circulation

Early signs of death (cellular death):

  • Pallor and loss of elasticity of skin
  • Eye changes
  • Primary flaccidity of muscles
  • Cooling of the body
  • Postmortem lividity/suggilation
  • Rigor mortis

Late signs of death:

  • Putrefaction
  • Adipocere
  • Mummification

Cadaveric lividity: Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the skin due to the collection of blood in most superficial layers of the dermis in the dependent parts of the body. Fixation of hypostasis occurs 6 – 12 hours after death and persists until putrefaction sets in.

questions.text: The life cycle of which of the following is depicted in the image below?
questions.solution:
The image given in question illustrates the life cycle of the Nipah virus, an RNA virus. Fruit bats serve as its natural host, and transmission occurs from bats and pigs to humans.

Nipah virus is an RNA virus from the family Paramyxoviridae and the genus Henipavirus. It is zoonotic, with fruit bats from the Pteropodidae family as its natural hosts. Transmission occurs from animals, such as bats and pigs, to humans, as well as between humans.Symptoms range from asymptomatic (subclinical) infection to acute respiratory illness and fatal encephalitis.

Currently, no treatment or vaccine exists for humans or animals, and supportive care is the main form of treatment for those infected. Nipah virus is also listed among the WHO's Blueprint priority diseases.

Other options:

Option A: Japanese encephalitis : Humans serve as dead-end hosts for the Japanese encephalitis (JE) virus, which is transmitted through the bite of Culex mosquitoes, particularly Culex tritaeniorhynchus and Culex vishnui, commonly found in India. The transmission cycle involves birds, mosquitoes, and humans.The JE virus also infects various non-human hosts, such as pigs and birds like pond herons.

The main transmission cycles are:
(a) Pig → Mosquito → Pig
(b) Bird → Mosquito → Bird

Herons act as reservoir hosts, while pigs function as amplifier hosts. Control measures focus on mosquito control, relocating pig farms away from human habitation, and vaccinating pigs.

Option B: Zika virus is transmitted to humans primarily through the bite of an infected Aedes species mosquito (Ae. aegypti and Ae. albopictus).

Anyone who lives in or travels to a region with risk of Zika infection, and has not already been infected with Zika virus can get it from mosquito bites. Once a person has been infected, they are likely to be protected from future infections

A pregnant woman can pass Zika virus to her fetus during pregnancy. Zika is a cause of microcephaly and other severe fetal brain defects. Zika virus has also been found in breast milk. Possible Zika virus infections have been identified in breastfeeding babies, but Zika virus transmission through breast milk has not been confirmed.
Zika can be passed through sexual intercourse, even if the infected person does not have symptoms at the time.
To date, there have not been any confirmed blood transfusion transmission cases in the United States. There are reports of laboratory acquired Zika virus infections, although the route of transmission was not clearly established in all cases
 

Option D: Rabies is a fatal infection of the central nervous system transmitted by the bite of a rabid animal. It is caused by rhabdoviruses. These viruses are enveloped, rod or bullet shaped and contain single-stranded RNA. This virus attaches to the cells via its glycoprotein spikes and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor acts as the cellular receptor.

questions.solution:
The image shown above is of the kata thermometer which was used to measure the cooling power of air.

Option C: Dial or digital thermometers are used to record temperatures inside an ice-lined refrigerator.

A dry and wet bulb hygrometer consists of two identical thermometers - a dry bulb thermometer and a wet-bulb thermometer, mounted side by side on a stand.  After obtaining the readings of both thermometers, the corresponding relative humidity can be found from psychrometric charts and slides.

questions.text: An infant was brought to the paediatric emergency department due to recurrent seizures and low blood sugar. The family history revealed that the infant's sibling had died suddenly at 4 months old. Laboratory tests showed elevated levels of dicarboxylic acid in both blood and urine. What is the underlying mechanism causing these symptoms?

choices.text: Impaired alpha oxidation of branched-chain fatty acids
Impaired beta-oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids
Impaired omega oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids
Impaired peroxisomal oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids

questions.solution:
The given clinical vignette is suggestive of medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase deficiency in which, there is impaired beta-oxidation of medium-chain fatty acids. This leads to the accumulation of dicarboxylic acids leading to dicarboxylic aciduria. It is characterized by:

  • Excretion of C6-C10 ω-dicarboxylic acids (medium-chain) in the urine.
  • Nonketotic hypoglycemia: due to the lack of ATP and acetyl CoA from β-oxidation (which is an activator of pyruvate carboxylase) to support gluconeogenesis.

Defects in medium-chain acyl-CoA dehydrogenase have been identified as a cause of sudden infant death syndrome (SIDS).

Omega-oxidation is an alternative way of fatty acid oxidation in the body when the beta-oxidation enzymes are either saturated or defective. Omega oxidation converts excess fatty acids to dicarboxylic acids that are soluble and hence can be excreted out via urine.

Other options:

Option A: Impaired Alpha oxidation leads to Refsum’s disease.

The manifestation of classic adult Refsum's disease includes

  • Retinitis pigmentosa
  • Peripheral neuropathy
  • Ataxia
  • Ichthyosis
  • Anosmia
  • Deafness
  • Occasionally cardiac arrhythmias

Option C: Medium-chain acyl CoA dehydrogenase deficiency will lead to increased (not impaired) utilization of the omega oxidation pathway, resulting in overproduction of dicarboxylic acids.

Option D: Impaired peroxisomal oxidation of very long-chain fatty acids (VLCFA) causes Zellweger (cerebrohepatorenal) syndrome. It is a rare inherited disorder characterized by the absence of peroxisomal enzymes in all tissues leading to the accumulation of C26—C38 polyenoic acids in brain tissue.

The clinical manifestation of Zellweger syndrome includes:

  • Facial deformities resembling Down syndrome (Mongoloid facies, Hypertelorism, Frontal bossing, Upslanting palpebral fissure)
  • Brush field spots
  • Hypotonia and hyporeflexia
  • Seizures
  • Neurodevelopmental delay
  • Liver enlargement

questions.text: A patient is diagnosed with a condition affecting the conducting airways of the respiratory pathway through biopsy. After starting treatment, it is observed months later that new cells have proliferated. Which of the following cells is responsible for the recovery in this patient?
questions.solution:
The cells responsible for recovery and new cell proliferation following damage to the conducting airways are Clara cells.

Club cells, also known as Clara cells, are specialized secretory cells found in the bronchioles that do not possess cilia. They act as progenitor cells and help in bronchial regeneration after injury. They also secrete essential defense markers and contribute to the composition of mucus through the secretion of a nonmucinous material containing carbohydrates and proteins.

Other options:

Option A: Type II pneumocytes are stem cells that are found in the alveoli ( respiratory zone) and not in the conducting zone. They help in replenishing damaged Type I pneumocytes. These cells possess superoxide dismutase, making them more resistant to toxic oxygen radicals. As a result, they can survive, proliferate, and differentiate into Type I cells to restore the normal alveolar architecture

Option C: Neuroendocrine cells or Kulchitsky cells form part of the neuroendocrine system of Amine precursor uptake and decarboxylation (APUD) cells. These cells manufacture amines and store and secrete biologically active peptides like Substance P and Vasoactive intestinal peptide (VIP). They are not involved in tissue regeneration.

Option D: Pulmonary alveolar macrophages (PAM) or dust cells originate from the bone marrow and possess active phagocytic abilities. They play a role in engulfing small particles that manage to bypass the mucociliary escalator and reach the alveoli. They do not possess stem cell function.

questions.text: A 35-year-old lady is diagnosed with Hashimoto thyroiditis. She has antibodies against the thyroid peroxidase enzyme. Which of the following function is not affected by this enzyme?
questions.solution:
Iodide trapping (iodide uptake) is not catalyzed by thyroid peroxidase. It occurs with the help of an iodide pump.

Thyroid peroxidase catalyses oxidation, organification(iodination) and coupling.

Steps in synthesis and secretion of thyroid hormone: 

  • Iodide uptake: The basolateral sodium-iodide symporter (NIS) actively takes up I-(iodide) from the circulation into the follicular cells. It is then transported into the colloid through a pendrin (chloride-iodide) transporter 
  • Thyroglobulin synthesis: Thyroglobulin (Tg), is a large glycoprotein rich in tyrosine residues. It is synthesized by follicular cells.
  • Iodination of thyroglobulin: The process of incorporating iodine into the tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin, leading to the formation of iodothyronine. This is regulated by the thyroid peroxidase (TPO) enzyme. TPO has three functions: 
    • Oxidation: TPO oxidizes I- to I2 (iodine)  in the presence of H2O2
    • Organification: TPO links tyrosine residues of thyroglobulin with iodine (I2) to form monoiodotyrosine (MIT), diiodotyrosine (DIT)
    • Coupling reactions: TPO combines iodinated tyrosine residues to make MIT + DIT = T3 (triiodothyronine), DIT + DIT = T4 (tetraiodothyronine)
  • Storage: Thyroid hormones are bound to thyroglobulin and stored in the follicular lumen as colloids. The colloid has hormone reserves for 2-3 months
  • Release: Iodinated thyroglobulin is taken up by the thyroid follicles via endocytosis and fuses with lysosomes. It is cleaved by lysosomal proteolytic enzymes into MIT, DIT, T3, and T4. T4 (80%) and T3 (20%) are released into the blood
  • Peripheral T3 conversion: T4 undergoes deiodination in extrathyroidal tissue to form T3, which is the active form of the hormone

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding metabotropic neurotransmitters?

choices.text: They act through second messenger systems
They bind to cationic channels and increase influx of Na+
They bind to anionic channels and increase influx of Cl-
They inhibit the fusion of synaptic vesicle with the synaptic cleft

questions.solution:
Neurotransmitter receptors that act through second messenger systems are called metabotropic receptors.

Neurotransmitters bind to receptors on the post-synaptic membrane to activate ion channels in one of the two ways:

  • By gating ion channels directly (ionotropic receptors).
  • By activating a second messenger (metabotropic receptor) for a prolonged postsynaptic neu­ronal excitation or inhibition. Most commonly activated is a G-protein coupled membrane receptor.

The following four changes can occur usually after binding to a G-protein coupled receptor:

  • Opening specific ion channels through the post-synaptic cell membrane.
  • Activation of cyclic adenosine monophosphate (cAMP) or cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP) in the neuronal cell.
  • Activation of one or more intracellular enzymes. 
  • Activation of gene transcription. Activation of gene transcription is one of the most important effects of activation of the second messenger systems because gene transcription can cause the formation of new proteins within the neuron, thereby changing its metabolic machinery or its structure.

questions.text: In a population study, the value of the mean is 200. If the standard deviation is 20, 68% of the population will lie between?
questions.solution:
68% of the population will lie between 180- 220.

In a normal distribution curve, 68% of the values lie within the median +/- 1 standard deviation and the mean=median=mode. Since the mean = 200 and the standard deviation = 20:

68% of population will lie between Median +/- 1SD, that is, 200 +/- 20 = 180-220

95% of population lies between Median+/-2SD, 200+/- 2*20 = 160- 240

99% of population lies between Median+/-3SD, 200+/- 3*20 = 140- 260

Related Pearl: Variance, Deviation Scores and Standard Deviation

  • Deviation Scores
    • Deviation score of an element in a distribution is the difference between the mean of the distribution and the element itself, i.e., subtracting the distribution’s mean from the element.
    • It is usually denoted by the letter x
    • For example, if 29 and 15 are elements in a distribution that has a mean of 22, the deviation score of 29 would be (29 – 22) = 7 and the deviation score of 15 would be (15 – 22) = - 7.
    • The sum of all the deviation scores of elements in a distribution will be zero. 
  • Variance
    • Variance is used to measure how far a data is spread out.
    • Technically, variance of a distribution is the mean of the squares of all the deviation scores of the distribution.
    • If the variance is zero, it indicates that all the elements in the distribution are the same and that there is no variability.
    • Variance is sometimes called mean square.
    • Thus variance is calculated by the following steps:
    • Finding the deviation score of each element in the distribution.
    • Squaring each of the deviation scores.
    • Obtain the mean of all these squared deviation scores.
    • Population variance is symbolized as σ2 and is given by the formula:
    • Sample variance is denoted by symbol s2. This is the more commonly used in statistics than the population variance. In the formula for sample variance, the denominator is n-1 (and not N as it is in population variance).
  • Standard Deviation
    • By definition, the standard deviation is the square root of variance (σ2 or s2).
    • Thus, the standard deviation of a population denoted by just σ and the standard deviation of a sample is denoted by just s. Sometimes, it is also denoted by SD.
    • The formula for standard deviation of a sample (usually <30) is:
    • In population standard deviation, the denominator would be replaced by just N.
    • The standard deviation is useful, especially but not only in normal or approximately normal distributions, as the proportion of population within the given SD can be calculated.
    • A low SD would mean that the data are close to the mean but a high SD would mean that the data are more spread out.
    • The empirical rule of a normal distribution states that:
      • Approximately 68% of the distribution falls within one standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 95% of the distribution falls within two standard deviations of the mean.
      • Approximately 99.7% of the distribution falls within three standard deviations of the mean.

questions.text: A 38-year-old female patient had a trucut biopsy of a breast lump, and a test was performed on the specimen to confirm the HER2 neu mutation. Identify the technique used for this test.
questions.solution:
The technique shown in the image is fluorescent in situ hybridization (FISH).

FISH is a technique where cells are stained with fluorescent stains. It uses DNA probes that recognize sequences specific to particular chromosomal regions. FISH can be performed on prenatal samples, peripheral blood cells, touch preparations from cancer biopsies, and even fixed archival tissue sections. Uses include :

  • Numerical abnormalities of chromosomes e.g., aneuploidy.
  • Subtle microdeletions and rearrangements.
  • Complex translocations that are not demonstrable by routine karyotyping.
  • Gene amplification of HER2 in breast cancer or NMYC amplification in neuroblastomas.

Types of FISH:

1) Chromosomal painting: Each chromosome is identified by using a different colour of the fluorescent probe, however, each chromosome does not have a unique colour. Since the fluorescent dyes are limited.

2) Multicolour FISH: 23 distinct fluorescent colours made by mixing 5 fluorophores. Thus each chromosome is identified by a unique colour. It is also known as spectral karyotyping (SKY). It offers various advantages such as

Detects structural and numeric abnormalities in chromosomes.
Detects gene amplification and subtle microdeletions
Maps a newly isolated gene to its correct chromosomal loci
However, this process requires prior knowledge of the genes and chromosomes.

3) Interphase FISH: It is a rapid procedure of FISH, wherein growing cells are not needed. It is used in prenatal diagnosis and in tumour diagnosis.
The image shown is of a Multicolor FISH also known as Spectral karyotyping with a unique colour to each chromosome pair.

Other options:

Option B: Karyotyping is the process by which chromosomes are isolated, stained, and examined to find chromosomal anomalies. It is used in prenatal diagnosis, investigation of repeat pregnancy loss, investigation of children and adults suspected of having a chromosomal disorder, and subtyping of lymphomas and leukemias for the purpose of exact diagnosis, giving a prognosis, and treatment.

The karyotyping of a normal human male is given below.

Option C: Immunohistochemistry (IHC) is a technique that uses the specific binding between an antibody and antigen to detect and localize specific antigens in cells and tissue. It is commonly used to assist in the classification of neoplasms, determination of a metastatic tumor’s site of origin, and detection of tiny foci of tumor cells. It is increasingly used to provide predictive and prognostic information in testing for HER2 amplification in breast cancer.

Option D : Microarray technique is used to detect multiple (thousands) genetic abnormalities on a single slide.

questions.text: You work in the Infection Control Committee of the hospital and are assigned the task of inspecting the disinfection and sterilization protocols of the operating room. What procedure should be followed to sterilize the urethroscope used?
questions.solution:
The sterilization of scopes such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes is done by plasma sterilization.

Plasma contains ions, electrons, and neutral particles. This state is produced by the application of radio frequency energy to create an electromagnetic field through which hydrogen peroxide vapors are passed. This generates plasma containing free radicals of hydrogen and oxygen which are used to sterilize articles such as arthroscopes and urethroscopes.

Other options :

Options B and C: Gamma radiation and ethylene oxide gas sterilization is used for the sterilization of articles such as syringes, needles, catheters, and gloves.

Option D: Autoclaving is used to sterilize surgical linens, culture media, dressings, gloves, aprons, all instruments except sharps, suture materials except catgut.

questions.text: A tourist who has been travelling in India presents with complaints of abdominal pain and multiple episodes of watery diarrhea. He reports having food at a local restaurant the previous night. Which of the following antidiarrheal agents is used in this condition?
questions.solution:
The antidiarrheal agent used in the given clinical scenario is loperamide. 

The given clinical scenario of a tourist with abdominal pain, and multiple episodes of diarrhea following food intake at an unhygienic place is suggestive of traveler’s diarrhea and the serotype of E.Coli most likely responsible for these symptoms would be Enterotoxigenic E. coli (ETEC). Enterotoxigenic E.Coli is the most common cause of traveler's diarrhea. 

Loperamide is an opioid receptor agonist and slows intestinal motility by direct effects on the circular and longitudinal muscles. It reduces fecal volume and increases viscosity. It is used in traveler's diarrhea for symptomatic treatment in conjunction with antibiotics. It is avoided in patients with dysentery. 

Other options: 

Option A: Octreotide is a somatostatin analog effective in treating severe secretory diarrhea that occurs due to hormone-secreting tumors in the GIT and pancreas. Its use is limited in traveler's diarrhea. 

Option C: Rifaximin is an antibiotic used in the treatment of traveler's diarrhea. It is an alternative to Azithromycin due to poor absorption. 

Option D: Bismuth subsalicylate is an over-the-counter (OTC) preparation used as an antidiarrheal agent. It is used in the treatment of traveler's diarrhea but is not preferred over loperamide due to a requirement for large doses, and salicylate toxicity, especially in high-risk groups (pregnancy, children, and individuals who take aspirin).

questions.text: The graph shows the drug-receptor interaction. Identify the line that depicts action of the antagonist.
questions.solution:
Line C depicts the action of an antagonist.

The receptor is postulated to exist in two forms: the inactive form (Ri) and the activated form (Ra). An antagonist binds to Ri and Ra in relative same amounts as in the absence of any drug (Ri~Ra). Thus, in this situation, no change in activity is observed (Line C).

The presence of the antagonist at the receptor site will block access of agonists to the receptor and prevent the agonist effect. Such blocking action is termed as neutral antagonism, for example, flumazenil on GABA receptors.

Other options:

  • Line A depicts full agonist, where the drug shifts maximum receptors to Ra pool. (Ra>>Ri)
  • Line B depicts partial agonists, which bind to the same receptors and activate them but not as much as full agonists, even at their maximum concentrations.
  • Line D depicts inverse agonists, where the majority of the receptors are shifted to inactivated state than activated state (Ri>Ra). Here, the effects are opposite to those produced by conventional agonists at that receptor.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases uric acid in urine?
questions.solution:
Probenecid is a uricosuric agent that promotes the excretion of uric acid.

Probenecid is used to decrease the body pool of urate in patients with chronic gout. The drug acts by inhibiting the organic anion transporter, particularly URAT-1 in the renal tubules that are involved in uric acid reabsorption. It is used as an adjuvant to allopurinol in chronic gout and hyperuricemia.

Probenecid increases urinary urate levels. Plenty of fluids are given to avoid urate calculi formation. Probenecid should not be used in gouty patients with nephrolithiasis or with overproduction of uric acid.

Probenecid inhibits penicillin's urinary excretion, prolonging penicillin action by enhancing and sustaining their blood levels. It inhibits the urinary excretion of other drugs such as cephalosporins, sulfonamides, methotrexate, and indomethacin. Aspirin blocks the uricosuric action of the drug.

Other options: 

Option A: Colchicine acts by preventing the polymerization of microtubules by tubulin, this reduces neutrophil recruitment to inflamed tissue and also decreases the secretion of chemotactic factors by activated neutrophils. Overall it reduces the inflammatory response.

Option B: Febuxostat is a xanthine oxidase inhibitor that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid approved for the treatment of hyperuricemia in patients with gout.

Option D: Allopurinol by inhibiting the xanthine oxidase enzyme that prevents the conversion of xanthine to uric acid.

questions.text: Which of the following side effects are seen most commonly with Isotretinoin (13-cis-retinoic acid)?
questions.solution:
Isotretinoin is a vitamin A derivative which is highly teratogenic when orally administered. It is commonly used to treat cystic nodular acne. It inhibits the migration of neural crest cells during embryogenesis and affects the development of multiple organs. These defects are collectively termed retinoic acid embryopathy.

Embryopathy or developmental disorder of an embryo comprises a large variety of abnormalities and is more common than any individual defect. Specific anomalies may include ventriculomegaly, maldevelopment of the facial bones or cranium, microtia or anotia, micrognathia, cleft palate, conotruncal heart defects, and thymic aplasia or hypoplasia.

Isotretinoin also increases the risk of spontaneous abortions and stillbirths up to 40% in pregnancies exposed in the first quarter of this medicine. Presenting with pregnancy during treatment with isotretinoin is a failure of prevention strategies.

The guidelines for isotretinoin usage are as follows:

  • Isotretinoin is a teratogenic drug that should not be taken during pregnancy and nursing.
  • Patients should take 2 pregnancy tests before starting isotretinoin and take a monthly pregnancy test while on the medication, and another test 1 month after stopping the medication.
  • Two forms of birth control should be simultaneously used starting 1 month before treatment, during the entire course of treatment, and for 1 month after ceasing treatment with isotretinoin.
  • Isotretinoin should be reserved for the treatment of severe, nodulocystic acne and should not be used for milder forms of acne.

Other options:

Option B: Lithium is used in the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is a teratogen associated with Ebstein's anomaly which is a rare cardiac condition characterized by severe tricuspid regurgitation and right atrial enlargement.

Option C: Valproic acid is the anti-epileptic which confers the greatest risk to the developing fetus while used in pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of neural tube defects in the fetus.

Option D: Tetracyclines are associated with yellowish-brown discoloration of deciduous teeth when used after 25 weeks of gestation.

questions.text: Third part of vertebral artery is related to which of the following ?
questions.solution:
The third part of the vertebral artery (V3) is related to the area marked 2, which is the posterior arch of the first cervical vertebra or the atlas.

The given image shows the first cervical vertebra - atlas.

  • The area marked 1 is the posterior tubercle.
  • The area marked 2 is the posterior arch. The superior surface bears a groove for the of vertebral artery and venous plexus immediately behind.
  • The area marked 3 is the superior articular facet.
  • The area marked 4 is the posterior surface of the anterior arch. It gives attachment to the apex of dens from the second cervical vertebra. 

The vertebral artery arises from the first part of the subclavian artery. It passes through the foramina of transverse processes of C6 to C1 cervical vertebrae and enters the cranium through the foramen magnum. The vertebral arteries of both sides join to form the basilar artery. In its course, it is divided into four parts:

The first part, V1, begins at its origin from the subclavian artery and ends at its entry into the transverse process of the C6 cervical vertebra. This part is crossed by the inferior thyroid artery on both sides, and thoracic duct on the left side, and the right lymphatic duct on the right side. 

The second part, V2 is that part of the artery ascending through the foramina in the transverse process of the cervical vertebrae. 

The third part, V3 is curved backward behind the atlas. In this position, it lies in a groove on the posterior arch of the atlas. This part of the artery lies in the suboccipital triangle. 

The fourth part, V4 pierces the dura and arachnoid mater and unites with the contralateral vertebral artery to form the midline basilar artery at the lower border of pons.

questions.text: A 58-year-old male came to OPD with complaints of difficulty in falling asleep.He was prescribed the drug ramelton. What is the mechanism of action of this drug?
questions.solution:
Ramelton is an MT1 and MT2 receptor agonist.

Ramelteon is a synthetic analogue of melatonin. There are two melatonin receptors, MT1 and MT2, in the suprachiasmatic nucleus where MT1 receptors promote the sleep onset and MT2 receptors change the timing of the circadian system. Ramelteon acts as an agonist to both MT1 and MT2 receptors and is used in the treatment of sleep-onset insomnia.

Ramelteon is metabolized by the CYP450 enzyme system and should not be taken along with drugs or substances inhibiting CYPA12 enzyme (ciprofloxacin, zileuton, and fluvoxamine) fluconazole (CYP2C9). It should be cautiously used with rifampin, an enzyme inducer. This can lead to decreased function.

Side effects include dizziness, fatigue, somnolence, and an increase in prolactin levels. Ramelteon undergoes extensive first-pass metabolism its bioavailability is less than 2%.

Other drugs used in the management of Insomnia:

  • Benzodiazepines: Facilitate the action of GABA by increasing the frequency of opening of the GABA-mediated chloride channel. Examples include alprazolam, clonazepam, lorazepam, midazolam, oxazepam,temazepam, estazolam.(option A)
  • Barbiturates: Facilitate the action of GABA by increasing the opening duration of GABA GABA-mediated chloride channel. Examples include amobarbital, phenobarbital, butabarbital, and pentobarbital.
  • Orexin antagonist: Blocks orexins, neuropeptides that promote wakefulness. Examples include suvorexant and daridorexant. (option B)
  • 5HT receptor agonist: Affinity for 5HT1A > D2 receptor. Examples include buspirone(option D).
  • Newer hypnotics:  These drugs act like benzodiazepines. Zaleplon, zolpidem, and eszopiclone are the examples.

questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis is porphyria cutanea tarda. The false statement regarding the patient's illness is that the hepatic iron stores are normal. The hepatic iron stores are increased.

Porphyrias are a group of metabolic disorders caused by the deficiency/ abnormal functioning of enzymes involved in heme biosynthesis which leads to subsequent accumulation and excretion of porphyrins/their precursors.

Porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT) is a type of hepatic, cutaneous porphyria caused due to a deficiency in the enzyme uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase, which converts uroporphyrinogen III to coproporphyrinogen III. Mutations of the uroporphyrinogen decarboxylase (UROD) gene are present.

The accumulated porphyrins transported to the skin act as photosensitizers. Hence, the patients usually present with skin fragility and bullae on sun-exposed skin, in areas of repeated trauma such as the dorsal aspect of the hands, the forearms, face, and ears. The erosions produced by the rupture of skin lesions heal with purplish discoloration. Hypertrichosis, mottled pigmentary change, and scleroderma-like induration are associated features.

Diagnosis is made by the classical clinical feature of photosensitivity with elevated urine, stool, and plasma uroporphyrin with normal red cell uroporphyrin. 

PCT is the most readily treated form of porphyria. Management includes:

  • Phlebotomies to deplete iron, guided by serum ferritin level estimation.
  • Hydroxychloroquine to remove excess porphyrins from the liver. A low-dose hydroxychloroquine regimen is preferred to avoid hepatotoxicity.

questions.text: The following is a histopathological image of the thyroid mass. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The histopathological image shows the presence of amyloid-rich stroma (pinkish material) and nests of polygonal cells, which are findings suggestive of medullary carcinoma of thyroid.

Medullary carcinoma of the thyroid (MTC) arises from the parafollicular C cells. Most of MTC are sporadic. Some are associated with inheritable syndromes like familial MTC, MEN2A, and MEN2B, all of which are secondary to RET gene mutations.

Most patients present at 50–60 years and have a female preponderance. MTC secretes calcitonin, carcinoembryonic antigen (CEA), and adrenocorticotrophic hormone (ACTH).

Features of MTC

  • Painful neck mass with cervical lymphadenopathy
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia, or dyspnea if there is local invasion
  • Diarrhoea due to increased intestinal motility
  • Cushingoid habitus due to ectopic ACTH production
  • Blood-borne metastasis 

Microscopically, they consist of sheets of neoplastic cells separated by collagen and amyloid stroma. Raised calcitonin and CEA levels, and fine-needle aspiration biopsy of the mass helps in diagnosis.

Other options:

Option B: The image below shows Orphan Annie-eye nuclei with central clearing and margination of chromatin in papillary carcinoma of the thyroid.

Option C: Follicular carcinoma thyroid on histopathology may show uniform cells forming small follicles containing colloid (resembling normal thyroid gland) or sheets of cells without colloid.

Option D: Anaplastic carcinomas are poorly differentiated thyroid carcinomas with varied morphology, including giant cells or spindle-shaped cells or both. There is minimal follicular differentiation with intratumoral necrosis.

Related Pearl: Papillary thyroid carcinoma

  • Papillary carcinoma is the most common thyroid carcinoma.
  • Most common in iodine sufficient areas, children and in those exposed to ionizing radiation. 
  • Mean age of presentation is 3rd-4th decade; more common in women than men (2:1)
  • Usually cold nodule on the scan
  • Branching papillae and follicles with the fibrovascular stalk, Psammoma bodies
  • Nuclear changes: Optically clear - Ground glass or Orphan Annie eye nuclei, pseudo-inclusions, nuclear grooves.
  • Lymph node metastasis is common
  • Lateral aberrant thyroid denotes a cervical lymph node invaded by papillary carcinoma.
  • Dysphagia, dysphonia and dyspnea are associated with local invasion
  • Most common sites of metastasis : lung > liver > bone > brain
  • Excellent prognosis, with a 10-year survival rate in excess of 95%.

questions.text: Cephalosporins are useful in all of the following infections except _______.
questions.solution:
Cephalosporins are not useful in Listeriosis which is caused by Listeria monocytogenes.

L. monocytogenes is a short, gram-positive, non-spore-forming bacteria. It enters the body through the GIT after ingestion of contaminated food such as cheese or vegetables. questions.text: A pathologist used Von Kossa stain in a biopsy sample of a brain tumour. Choose the correct option regarding the finding and deposition identified.
questions.solution:
The Von Kossa is a black stain used for staining calcium.

Calcification is often found in slowly growing brain tumours, such as oligodendrogliomas, meningiomas, and Craniopharyngiomas. The hallmark of malignant disease is haemorrhage which is frequently found in glioblastoma multiforme (GBM). 

The following staining techniques are used for calcium:

  • Hematoxylin and eosin (H&E) :
    • Calcium forms a blue-black lake with hematoxylin 
  • Azan stain :
    • Used to distinguish osteoid from the mineralized bone
  • Alizarin red S stain :
    • Forms an orange-red lake with calcium
    • Works best with small amounts of calcium
    • An example is Michaelis–Gutmann (MG) bodies, seen in malakoplakia
  • Von Kossa method : 
    • Useful for tissues containing large amounts of phosphates and carbonates, such as bone
    • Silver ions react with phosphate in the presence of acidic material
    • Silver phosphate gets degraded to silver in the presence of light, giving black colour

questions.text: A 60 year-old-woman comes with complaints of sudden onset blindness of the right eye, with throbbing headache in the right temporal region associated with jaw claudication. On examination, a thickened tender cord-like structure can be felt in the temple. Temporal artery biopsy shows the following. Which among the following is true about this condition?

choices.text: Lesions are distributed throughout the entire length of the artery
Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation
T cell infiltrates are predominantly CD8+
Fragmentation is seen in external elastic lamina

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and histology image is suggestive of giant cell/temporal arteritis. Classic lesions exhibit medial granulomatous inflammation.

Giant cell/temporal arteritis is a chronic inflammatory disorder of large to small-sized arteries that especially affects the arteries of the head. It is seen in people over 50 years of age.

It can affect the following arteries:

  • Superficial temporal artery: Intense facial pain or headache along the course of the artery
  • Ophthalmic arteries: Sudden and permanent diplopia or blindness
  • Aorta: Giant-cell aortitis
  • Vertebral arteries

A biopsy is needed to confirm the diagnosis. However, a negative biopsy cannot exclude the diagnosis of giant cell arteritis because the lesions are focally distributed(option A), leaving long segments of the artery normal. Hence, the biopsy sample may be taken from the normal part of the artery, leading to a false-negative report. For the same reason, an adequate biopsy requires at least a 1-cm segment.

Biopsy findings of giant cell arteritis include:

  • Classic lesions are primarily medial granulomatous inflammation.
  • These lesions involve the internal elastic lamina, leading to elastic lamina fragmentation.(option D)
  • There is intimal thickening that reduces the luminal diameter.
  • There is an infiltrate with T cells (CD4+ > CD8+)(option C), macrophages, and multinucleated giant cells (75% of specimens).

The image below shows internal elastic lamina fragmentation (black arrow) and giant cells (yellow arrow) in a cerebral artery. 

Corticosteroids and anti-TNF therapies are used for treatment.

questions.text: An infant was brought with failure to thrive. On examination, the infant appears floppy with an enlarged tongue, hypotonia, skeletal muscle weakness, and hepatomegaly. The chest X-ray is shown below. Laboratory investigations reveal elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), lactate dehydrogenase (LDH), and urine glucose tetrasaccharide. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
From the above-given clinical scenario and the radiograph showing cardiomegaly, Pompe's disease is the most likely diagnosis.

Pompe's disease (Type 2 glycogen storage disease) is an autosomal recessive disorder that occurs due to α-1,4-glucosidase (acid maltase) deficiencyleading to lysosomal glycogen accumulation in cardiac, skeletal, and smooth muscle cells. It can appear within weeks or months after birth (infantile Pompe disease) or may appear late in juvenile, childhood, or adulthood disease (late-onset Pompe disease).

The clinical symptoms of Pompe disease are hypotonia (floppy infant), skeletal muscle weakness, hepatomegaly, hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, macroglossia, and chest X-ray image shows cardiomegaly. 

Laboratory findings will show elevated levels of serum creatine kinase (CK), aspartate transaminase (AST), alanine transaminase (ALT), and lactate dehydrogenase (LDH). Urine glucose tetrasaccharide, a glycogen breakdown metabolite, is a reliable biomarker for disease severity and treatment response.

Muscle biopsy shows the presence of vacuoles that stain positively for glycogen. It is diagnosed by detecting the decreased activity of the enzyme, α-1,4-glucosidase in the dried blood spots, leukocytes, blood mononuclear cells, muscle, or cultured skin fibroblasts.

Other options:

Option A: Von Gierke disease occurs due to a deficiency of glucose-6-phosphatase. Patients present commonly in 3-4 months of age with hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, hepatomegaly, growth retardation, hyperuricemia, and hyperlipidemia.

Option C: McArdle disease occurs due to myophosphorylase deficiency leading to reduced ATP generation. The typical manifestations are myoglobinuria (secondary to rhabdomyolysis), muscle pain and cramps after heavy exercise. This pain may reduce after a brief period of rest and the patient may be able to perform an exercise. This is called the second wind phenomenon. Cardiomyopathy is not seen in this condition.

Option D: Tarui disease (Type VII glycogen storage disorder) occurs due to the deficiency of muscle phosphofructokinase. The main clinical features are exercise intolerance, cramps, hemolytic anemia, and myoglobinuria. There is no hypertrophic cardiomyopathy.

questions.text: The family pedigree chart of a child with inherited anaemia is given below. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The pedigree chart given is suggestive of an autosomal dominant inheritance which is seen in hereditary spherocytosis.

Such an inheritance has a vertical pattern in pedigree charts where individuals of each generation are affected (parents and children). Males and females are equally affected and each affected individual has a 50% chance of passing the deleterious gene to their offspring.

The following flow chart helps in making out the pattern of inheritance from a given pedigree chart.

According to the above flowchart:

Step 1: All affected individuals have an affected parent. Since multiple generations are affected it is a dominant inheritance pattern.

Step 2: Male-to-male transmission is present. The disorder thus has an autosomal dominant inheritance pattern.

Thalassemia is autosomal recessive, which means both parents must be affected with or carriers for the disease to transfer it to the next generation. It is caused by mutations or deletions of the Hb genes, resulting in underproduction or absence of alpha or beta chains

Glucose 6 phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency is inherited in an X-linked recessive manner and symptoms are more common in males.

Sickle cell anaemia occurs due to a mutation when negatively charged glutamine is replaced by a neutral valine at the sixth position of the beta-globin chain. The mutation is inherited in an autosomal recessive manner.

questions.text: A 4-year-old boy presents with low-grade fever, inspiratory stridor, and barking cough for the past 5 days. His chest X-ray showed the following. Which among the following is not indicated in the treatment of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and an X-ray showing the narrowing of the subglottic region of the trachea (steeple sign) are suggestive of croup (laryngotracheobronchitis). Since it is a viral infection, antibiotics like cefotaxime are not indicated in their treatment.

The median age for laryngotracheobronchitis is 3 months to 5 years. It is caused due to viral infection of the glottic and subglottic regions. Parainfluenza virus is a common cause of laryngotracheobronchitis

Clinical features include low-grade fever, hoarseness of voice, and a barking cough. There may be associated inspiratory stridor. Diagnosis is usually clinical. A lateral radiograph of the neck will reveal the steeple sign due to subglottic narrowing (shown below). 

Treatment of croup involves:

  • Racemic epinephrine nebulization - It constricts pre-capillary arterioles in the upper airway mucosa and decreases capillary hydrostatic pressure, leading to fluid resorption from the interstitial space and reduction of edema. The indications for the administration of nebulized epinephrine are:
    • moderate to severe stridor at rest
    • the possible need for intubation
    • respiratory distress
    • hypoxia
  • Oral dexamethasone - Indicated in all the grades of croup. Corticosteroids reduce laryngeal edema through their anti-inflammatory action. IM dexamethasone and nebulized budesonide have an equal clinical effect. Corticosteroids should not be administered to children with varicella or tuberculosis as they may worsen the disease.
  • Severe croup requires urgent hospitalization with oxygen inhalation for hypoxemic child(SpO2 <92 %)
    (A helium-oxygen mixture (heliox) may be considered for severe croup when intubation is being considered)
  • Antibiotics are not indicated.

Most children that have croup can be managed safely at home. Indications for hospitalization:

  • Progressive stridor
  • Severe stridor at rest
  • Respiratory distress
  • Hypoxia
  • Cyanosis
  • Depressed mental status
  • Poor oral intake
  • Need for reliable observation

questions.text: Coagulation profile monitoring is required for which of the following drugs?
questions.solution:
Coagulation profile monitoring is required while using lepirudin.

Lepirudin is a parenteral direct thrombin inhibitor, which is a recombinant form of hirudin extracted from the saliva of leech. Its action is independent of anti-thrombin, which means it can reach and inactivate fibrin-bound thrombin in thrombi. It is excreted by the kidney and should be used with great caution in patients with renal insufficiency as no antidote exists. 

Its most adverse reaction is bleeding. The risk of bleeding can be reduced by implementing an appropriate monitoring and dose adjustment strategy. Thus, coagulation profile monitoring is required for lepirudin.

Like heparin, lepirudin must be administered parenterally and is monitored by aPTT. Lepirudin was approved for use in patients with thrombosis related to heparin-induced thrombocytopenia (HIT). Its production was discontinued by the manufacturer in 2012.

Other options :

Option B - Enoxaparin is a low molecular weight heparin (LMWH) that inhibits activated factor X with less effect on thrombin. Hence, it has a smaller effect on the coagulation profile and does not need monitoring. 

Option C - Fondaparinux avidly binds antithrombin, resulting in efficient inactivation of factor Xa. It is effective in the prevention and treatment of venous thromboembolism and does not appear to cross-react with pathologic HIT antibodies in most individuals. Like LMWH, it does not require monitoring of the coagulation profile.

Option D - Dabigatran is an oral direct thrombin inhibitor approved for the reduction in risk of stroke and systemic embolism with nonvalvular atrial fibrillation, treatment of venous thromboembolism (VTE) and VTE prophylaxis following hip or knee replacement surgery. It does not require monitoring of coagulation profile.

questions.text: A mother of a 1-month-old infant is concerned about her baby's slow weight gain. The baby is exclusively breastfed and otherwise healthy. What is the most likely explanation in this case?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the slow weight gain in an exclusively breastfed and otherwise healthy infant is most likely due to insufficient feeding, i.e., insufficient intake of the hind milk.

While breastfeeding, the mother should allow the complete emptying of one breast before switching over to the other. It is because the baby needs both foremilk and hindmilk for optimum growth. 

Foremilk is the one that is secreted during the initial feed. It is watery and quenches the thirst of the baby. It is rich in proteins, sugar, vitamins, minerals, and water. Hindmilk is rich in fat and provides energy. It gives a sense of satiety to the baby. Hindmilk comes towards the end of the feed. 

The composition of breast milk varies at different time points of lactation to suit the needs of the baby.

  • Colostrum is secreted in small quantities during the first 3 to 4 days. It is thick, and yellow and contains a large number of antibodies, immune-competent cells, and vitamins A, D, E, and K. 
  • Transitional milk is the one that is seen after 3-4 days until 2 weeks and has an increased fat and sugar content while the protein and immunoglobulin content reduces.
  • Mature milk is secreted after transitional milk. It is essential for the optimum growth of the baby as it contains all the nutrients. It is thinner and more watery.
  • A mother who delivers before 37 weeks secretes preterm milk that contains proteins, sodium, iron, immunoglobulin, and calories as needed by the preterm infant.

The given image shows watery foremilk (left) and hindmilk which is rich in fat (right).

Other options:

Option A: Lactose intolerance can present in newborn infants with severe osmotic diarrhea at the commencement of breastfeeding. However, primary lactose intolerance rarely manifests in children below 5 years of age.

Option C: Foremilk is secreted initially during breastfeeding. So even in short sessions of breastfeeding, foremilk intake is adequately met.

Option D: Milk protein allergy is generally associated with cow's milk. The child here is exclusively breastfed; hence, milk protein allergy is unlikely.
