questions.text: Identify the type of study from the following design:
questions.solution:
The design given is of a case-control study. It proceeds from effect to cause and is done after the exposure and outcome have occurred.

It tries to determine the possible exposure factors after a known disease incidence. This is the first approach to test causal hypotheses and uses controls to support or refute an inference.

Retrospective or historical cohort study, on the other hand, tries to compare the risk of developing a disease to some already known exposure factors. Ex: risk of lung cancer in uranium miners, risk of angiosarcoma in persons exposed to polyvinyl chloride etc.

Retrospective cohort studies are more economical and quicker than prospective cohort studies.

Related Pearl: Case Control Study

In a case-control study, progression is from effect (disease) to cause (exposure) as the outcome or disease has already occurred. It is also called a retrospective study.

Design of case-control study:

 

  • Steps of case control study:
    • Selection of cases and controls
    • Matching
    • Measurement of exposure
    • Analysis in the form of exposure rates, risk ratio, and odds ratio
  • Advantages of case control study:
    • Easy to carry out, rapid and inexpensive
    • Requires few subjects, no risk to subjects
    • Used to investigate rare diseases
    • Different etiological factors can be studied and risk factors can be identified
    • No attrition problems, minimal ethical problems
  • Disadvantages of case control study:
    • Relies on memory or past records giving rise to bias
    • Selection of appropriate control groups is difficult
    • Incidence cannot be measured
    • Does not distinguish between causes and associated factors
    • Not suited for evaluation of therapy or prophylaxis
    • Representativeness of the cases and controls is often inadequate

questions.text: A 24-year-old patient complains of diarrhea, vomiting and abdominal pain that was aggravated on ingestion of food since 1 week. The stool microscopy reveals the following. The appropriate treatment for this condition would be ______
questions.solution:
The given clinical picture and the stool microscopy image showing the rhabditiform larva are suggestive of Strongyloidiasis. The most appropriate treatment for this condition would be Ivermectin.

Strongyloides stercoralis is a parasitic nematode known for causing chronic diarrhea, particularly in immunocompromised individuals such as those with HIV. In this case, only larvae (and not ova) are seen in the stool, which is characteristic of Strongyloides infection due to its autoinfective cycle, where the larvae hatch inside the intestine and are passed in the stool.

Strongyloidiasis:

Strongyloides are ovoviviparous. The transmission of infection occurs through penetration of the skin by filariform larvae in the soil. Then, they migrate to the small intestine. The larvae moult twice and become adult female worms in the small intestine. The eggs laid in the mucosa of the intestine hatch immediately releasing the rhabditiform larva (L1 stage). These rhabditiform larvae in the bowel can develop directly into filariform larvae that penetrate the colonic wall or perianal skin and enter the circulation to repeat the migration. This establishes ongoing internal reinfection.

The life cycle of strongyloides is shown below.

It is generally an asymptomatic condition. There may be cutaneous, pulmonary, and intestinal manifestations in some cases. Pulmonary manifestations occur when the larva escapes from the pulmonary capillaries into the alveoli leading to bronchopneumonia, chronic bronchitis, and asthmatic symptoms. 

The term larva currens (meaning ‘racing larvae’) has been applied to the rapidly progressing linear or serpiginous urticarial tracks caused by migrating filariform larvae of Strongyloides stercoralis. These often follow autoinfection and start perianally. Disseminated Strongyloidiasis is seen in immunodeficient individuals.

Larva currens is shown in the image below.

Visceral larva migrans is caused by the migration of larvae of nonhuman species of nematodes that infect via the oral route. 

Etiological agents causing visceral larva migrans:

Human nematode: Ascaris lumbricoides, Strongyloides stercoralis.
Zoophilic nematode: Toxocara canis, toxocara cati, Angiostrongylus cantoniensis, Angiostrongylus costaricensis, Anisakis.
Non human nematode: Filarial species, Brugia pahangi, Brugia pate

Laboratory diagnosis of strongyloidiasis:

Eosinophilia and raised IgE levels.
Microscopic examination of the direct wet mount of the stool demonstrating rhabditiform larvae forms the definitive diagnosis
Stool culture and serological tests are also done

Treatment: Ivermectin is the preferred agent in the management of strongyloidiasis.

questions.text: The  fallopian tube is lined by ______.
questions.solution:
The lining epithelium of the fallopian tube is a single layer of ciliated columnar epithelium. 

The ciliated epithelial cells are predominant in the distal part of the fallopian tube. There is an increase in the height and number of cilia in these cells during the estrogenic phase of the menstrual cycle.

Other cells in the fallopian tube epithelium include:

  • Secretory or peg cells - maximally located in the proximal portion of the tube. These cells are active around the time of ovulation, and their secretions help in the capacitation of sperms.
  • Intraepithelial lymphocytes - may present occasionally. 

Related Pearl: Various Types of Epithelium, Their Location and Functions

questions.text: Follow-up treatment with which of the following is required in a patient who underwent a valve replacement surgery?
questions.solution:
Oral warfarin anticoagulation is a long-term treatment that is required after heart valve replacement. This treatment can prevent serious complications, such as embolism, thereby increasing patients' postoperative survival rates and quality of life.

Warfarin:

  • Uses of warfarin are acute deep vein thrombosis, pulmonary embolism, and preventing stroke or systemic embolization in patients with a mechanical heart valve.
  • Adverse effects of warfarin are bleeding, skin necrosis, purple toe syndrome, and fetal warfarin syndrome (hypoplasia of the nose, eye socket, hand bones, and growth retardation).
  • The therapeutic dose of warfarin is monitored by an INR range of 2-3. Warfarin toxicity can occur when the INR exceeds 4 and can lead to fatal bleeding. Treatment includes withholding warfarin, with vitamin K, and blood transfusions or fresh frozen plasma to replenish clotting factors.

In patients with mechanical heart valves:

  • The INR ratio recommended for the administration of warfarin in patients with mechanical heart valves is around 2.5-3.5.
  • Warfarin therapy is usually monitored by measuring prothrombin time.
  • Prothrombin time is sensitive to the reduction in levels of prothrombin, factor VII, and factor X.
  • International normalized ratio (INR) was developed to standardize the reporting of prothrombin time.

questions.text: In a village of 2000 people, you diagnosed a 10-year-old boy having diarrhea with cholera. 19 more similar cases occurred in the same village, out of which 5 succumbed to death. Which of the following parameters can be used to assess the killing power of the causative agent in the given outbreak?
questions.solution:
The case fatality rate represents the killing power of the disease.

Case fatality rate = Total number of deaths due to a particular disease X 100 / Total number of cases due to the same disease

The case-fatality rate is thus the proportion of people with a particular disease who die from that disease. It is a measure of the severity of the disease, and the deadliness of an outbreak, and may be used to evaluate any public health measures implemented. It is closely related to the virulence of the agent.

Due to changes in the agent, host, and environmental factors in different epidemics, the case fatality rate for the same disease may vary in different epidemics. It is typically used in acute infectious diseases. Eg: Food poisoning, measles, cholera, etc. 

Other options:

Option B: Proportional mortality rate is used to know the proportion of total death due to any particular cause. It does not indicate the risk of contracting or dying from the disease.

Option C: Crude death rate measures the rate at which the death is occurring from different causes in a given population, during a specified period. 

Crude death rate = number of deaths during the year X 1000/ Mid-year population

Option D: Specific death rate is used to identify particular groups or groups "at-risk" for preventive action. They help in comparison between different causes of death within the same population. 

Specific death rate due to cancer = Number of death from cancer during a calendar year X 1000/ Mid-year population

questions.text: What is the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked in the image is the Genioglossus muscle.

Genioglossus is one of the extrinsic muscles of the tongue which bring about the forward traction of the tongue to protrude its apex from the mouth. Hence, it is also called the safety muscle of the tongue.

Origin: The superior mental spine (also called the superior genial tubercle) of the mandible, located on the internal surface of the mandible near the symphysis (midline).
Insertion: The muscle fans out and inserts into the entire length of the inferior surface of the tongue and the body of the hyoid bone.

Acting bilaterally, the two muscles depress the central part of the tongue, making it concave from side to side. Acting unilaterally, the tongue diverges to the opposite side.

Other options:

Option B: Hyoglossus: depresses the tongue

Option C: Styloglossus: draws the tongue up and backward.

Option D: Palataglossus: elevate the posterior portion of the tongue

All muscles of tongue are derived from occipital myotomes, hence innervated by hypoglossal nerve, except palatoglossus which is derived from the pharyngeal arch and is supplied by vago-accessory nerve.

questions.text: Which of the following correctly identifies the type of cell junction within the blood testis barrier that can cross it from the bloodstream?
questions.solution:
The cell junctions within the blood testis barrier allowed to enter from the bloodstream are the tight junctions.

Sertoli cells form tight junctions with each other, forming a protective barrier known as the blood-testes barrier, which separates the testes from the bloodstream. This barrier selectively allows certain substances, such as testosterone, to pass through while preventing harmful substances that could potentially harm the maturing sperm. Important functions of the blood testes barrier are as follows:

  • It prevents the passing of large molecules from interstitial tissue and basal compartment to the tubular lumen.
  • It helps in maintaining the composition of the tubular fluid.
  • It protects the developing sperm from immunological attack and blood-borne noxious agents.

In the given image:

1- basal lamina, 2- spermatogonia, 3- primary spermatocyte, 4- secondary spermatocyte, 5- early spermatid, 6- late spermatid, 7- Sertoli cell, 8- tight junction (blood-testis barrier).

questions.text: The average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in her age group is called as __?
questions.solution:
The average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in her age group is called as total fertility rate.

Related Pearl: Fertility Indicators

  • Crude birth rate
    • It is the simplest measure of fertility although its usage is unsatisfactory.
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 estimated mid-year population in a given year.
    • Birth rate = No. of live births during the year x 1000/Estimated mid-year population
    • India, as per SRS bulletin 2018, had a birth rate of 20.0 per 1000 population
  • General Fertility Rate
    • It is the number of live births per 1000 women in the reproductive age group (15 - 49 years) in a given year.
    • GFR = Number of live births in an area in a year x 1000/Mid-year population of women in the reproductive age in the same area in the same year.
    • It is a better indicator of fertility than crude birth rate
    • The demerit of this indicator is that not all women in the denominator are exposed to childbirth
  • Age-specific fertility rates
    • It is the number of live births in a year to 1000 women in any specified age group.
    • It is a more precise measure of fertility and is also a sensitive indicator of family planning achievement.
    • ASFR = Number of live births in a particular age group x 1000/Mid-year female population of the same age group.
  • Total Fertility Rate
    • It represents the average number of children a woman would have if she were to pass through her reproductive years bearing children at the same rates as the women in each age group now.
    • It is the sum of all age specific fertility rates multiplied by 5.
    • This measure gives the approximate magnitude of completed family size.
  • Gross Reproductive Rate
    • It is the average number of girls that would be born to a woman if she experiences the current fertility pattern throughout her reproductive span, assuming no mortality.
  • Net Reproduction Rate
    • It is the number of daughters a newborn girl will bear during her lifetime assuming age-specific fertility and mortality rates.
    • NRR is a demographic indicator.
    • NRR of 1 is equivalent of approximately the 2 child norm.
    • If the NRR is less than 1, then the reproductive performance of the population is said to be inadequate.

questions.text: A 58-year-old man presented with a history of lymph node enlargement in his neck and axillae for the past 3 weeks. Investigations revealed mild anemia with leukocytosis of 40,000/mm3. The peripheral blood smear is shown in the image below. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given scenario is suggestive of chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL). CLL is a tumor of mature B cells and the most common leukemia in adults.

Patients with CLL present with nonspecific symptoms like easy fatigability, weight loss, and anorexia. Generalized lymphadenopathy and hepatosplenomegaly are present in about 50-60% of cases. There is also increased susceptibility to infections due to disruption of immune processes.

The peripheral smear, as shown in the image below, typically shows small round lymphocytes with condensed chromatin and scant cytoplasm (indicated by arrows). Some of these cells get disrupted while preparing the smear; these cells are called smudge cells (indicated by arrowheads).

Other options:

Option A: Acute lymphoblastic lymphoma (ALL) is a tumor of immature B or T cells and the most common leukemia in children. The peripheral blood smear shows lymphoblasts with condensed nuclear chromatin, small nucleoli, and scant agranular cytoplasm.

Option C: Multiple myeloma is a neoplasm of plasma cells. It is also typically associated with punched-out bony lesions, hypercalcemia, and renal. Bone marrow aspirate shows plasma cells with multiple nuclei and prominent nucleoli. Serum protein electrophoresis shows a spike of M protein (monoclonal immunoglobulin).

Option D: Waldenström macroglobulinemia is a hyperviscosity syndrome caused due to excess amounts of monoclonal IgM secreted by plasma cells. It is a type of lymphoplasmacytic lymphoma, with bone marrow aspirate showing small lymphocytes with variable degrees of plasma differentiation.

questions.text: A 60 year old female patient came with complaints of  a sudden, intense urge to urinate followed by an involuntary loss of urine. Which of the following drugs cannot be used for the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of urge incontinence and bethanechol is not used for the management of this condition. It is a muscarinic agonist that activates M1, M2, and M3 receptors and causes smooth muscle contraction. It is mainly used in post-operative and neurogenic ileus and urinary retention.

Mirabegron is a β3-adrenergic receptor agonist which is used for bladder incontinence. Activation of this receptor in the bladder leads to detrusor muscle relaxation and increased bladder capacity. This action prevents voiding and provides relief for those with an overactive bladder and urinary incontinence. (Option A)

Oxybutynin and solifenacin are muscarinic antagonists that increase bladder capacity by blocking M3 receptors on the detrusor. This results in the relaxation of the bladder. Tolterodine also shows a preference for muscarinic receptors in the bladder. (Option C and D)

  • Lower the frequency of bladder contractions
  • Alter bladder sensation during filling

questions.text: A 40-year-old man presents with gynecomastia. Ultrasonography (USG) reveals a 1-cm solid mass within the body of the testis. His serum testosterone is 600 ng/dL and estradiol is 35 pg/mL. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A 40-year-old man presenting with gynecomastia, testicular mass, and increased sex hormones is most likely to have  Leydig cell tumor of the testis.

Leydig cell tumor:

  • It is the most common sex-cord stromal type of testicular neoplasm.
  • It is mostly benign and invariably unilateral.
  • Most cases occur between 20 and 60 years of age; however, it can present at any age.
  • The most common presenting feature is testicular swelling or gynecomastia (~15% of cases).
  • In children, hormonal effects manifested primarily as sexual precocity, are the dominant features.
  • Tumors of Leydig cells may secrete androgens and estrogens, and even corticosteroids.

Grossly: Golden brown, homogeneous circumscribed nodules <5 cm in diameter.

Histologically:

  • large, round, or polygonal cells
  • round central nucleus and prominent nucleoli
  • abundant granular eosinophilic cytoplasm containing lipid droplets, vacuoles, or lipofuscin pigment
  • crystalloids of Reinke, rod-shaped eosinophilic cytoplasmic bodies are seen in about 25% of the tumors

Other options:

Option A: Spermatocytic tumor mainly occurs in older adults as a slow-growing testicular mass. They do not secrete any hormones.

Option B: Sertoli cell tumor mostly presents as a painless testicular mass. They are usually hormonally silent. Hence, gynecomastia and precocious puberty are very rare

Option C: Granulosa cell tumor usually presents as a slow-growing and non-functioning testicular mass. Gynecomastia is rare.

questions.text: A 50-year-old lady with a known case of hypothyroidism presents with pain and burning of the lateral half of the palm. On examination, her palms appear as shown below and Phalen's test is positive. What is the likely structure under which the affected nerve is compressed?
questions.solution:
The image shows atrophy of thenar eminence as seen in carpal tunnel syndrome. It is due to compression of the median nerve where it passes under the flexor retinaculum in the wrist.

Patients present with pain and paresthesia over the distribution of the median nerve. There may be a weakness of thumb opposition. In chronic cases, the thenar eminence is wasted.

Tinel's sign will be positive. This sign is elicited by percussing over the median nerve, reproducing symptoms. In Phalen's test,  the symptoms are reproduced by holding the wrists in full flexion for 60 seconds.

Carpal tunnel syndrome can be associated with rheumatoid arthritis, pregnancy, chronic renal failure, acromegaly, hypothyroidism, and gout. The diagnosis is usually made on clinical grounds but nerve conduction studies can confirm the diagnosis.

The following image shows Phalen's test.

Other options 

Option A- Ligament of Struthers connects the medial epicondyle and the humerus. It is associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve and produces similar symptoms as carpal tunnel syndrome. However, Phalen's test is negative.

Option B- Bicipital aponeurosis is the insertion of the biceps in the cubital fossa. It is also associated with pronator syndrome due to the involvement of the median nerve. Phalen's test is negative.

Option C- Guyon's canal: The ulnar nerve can get compressed while passing through Guyon's canal.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with weakness in his lower limbs. On motor examination, the resident taps on the patellar tendon with a knee hammer and there was a sudden kicking movement of the knee. Which of the following is true about the given reflex?

choices.text: Root value of the reflex is L5 - S2
It is a monosynaptic stretch reflex
Efferent is acted upon γ-motor neurons of the hamstring muscles

questions.solution:
From the given scenario, the resident is performing a knee jerk reflex (patellar reflex) on this patient. 

Knee jerk or patellar reflex is elicited by tapping the patellar tendon resulting in contraction of the quadriceps muscle. It is an example of a deep tendon reflex or myotatic stretch reflex as stretching the muscle causes reflex contraction. 

The reflex arc in the knee jerk reflex consists of only one synapse between afferents and efferents. Hence, it is also an example of a monosynaptic reflex. 

Reflex arc of knee jerk reflex -  

Tapping the tendon causes a stretch of the muscle spindle which is present within the muscle. The muscle spindle is a sensory proprioceptor responsible for identifying the length of the muscle fibers. The Ia afferent sensory fibers in the muscle spindles are activated in response to the stretch. These Ia afferent fibers go to the spinal cord at the dorsal root ganglia and stimulate the alpha-motor neurons. This results in the contraction of the muscle that was initially stretched. The neurotransmitter at the central synapse is glutamate.

The femoral nerve L2-L4 mediates the patellar reflex.

 

Clinical aspect: 

  • Brisk, hyperactive deep tendon reflexes are seen in upper motor neuron lesions affecting the descending spinal tracts like the corticospinal tract. 
  • Hypoactive or absent reflexes are seen in lower motor neuron lesions or the lesions affecting the components of the reflex arc. Absent reflexes can be seen in diabetes, deep sleep, coma, nerve block, spinal anesthesia etc. 
  • The pendular knee jerk, in which tapping the patellar tendon results in to-and-fro movements of the limb is seen in cerebellar lesions. The increased swinging occurs due to hypotonia of both flexors and extensors leading to a lack of restraint on each other.

questions.text: A person has consumed a meal rich in protein. Which of the following substances would primarily be secreted that would cause an increase in the secretion of acid in the stomach?
questions.solution:
When a meal rich in protein has been consumed, the increase in the secretion of acid in the stomach is likely due to gastrin. 

The peptides and amino acids have a special stimulatory effect on the gastric cells located in the pyloric antrum, causing the secretion of gastrin. This further increases the hydrochloric acid secretion. 

Stimuli that increase acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Distension of stomach
  • Peptides
  • Calcium
  • Increased vagal discharge

Stimuli that decrease acid and gastrin secretion:

  • Gastric acid
  • Secretin family - secretin, glucagon, VIP, GIP
  • Somatostatin
  • Calcitonin

Related Pearl: Stimuli for gastric secretion

Stimuli

Mechanism

Applied aspects

Vagal stimulation

Direct pathway

Vagus nerve innervates parietal cells and stimulates H+ secretion directly.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is Ach, the receptor on the parietal cells is muscarinic (M3)

The second messengers for CCK are IP3 and increased intracellular [Ca2+].

Atropine, a cholinergic muscarinic antagonist, inhibits H+ secretion by blocking the direct pathway, which uses ACh as a neurotransmitter. However, it does not block H+ secretion completely because it does not inhibit the indirect pathway, which uses GRP as a neurotransmitter

Indirect pathway

Vagus nerve innervates G cells and stimulates gastrin secretion, which then stimulates H+ secretion.

The neurotransmitter at these synapses is GRP (not ACh).

Vagotomy eliminates both direct and indirect pathways.

Gastrin

Released in response to eating a meal (small peptides, distension of the stomach, vagal stimulation).

Stimulates H+ secretion by interacting with the cholecystokinin B (CCKB) receptor on the parietal cells.

The second messenger for gastrin on the parietal cell is IP3/Ca2+.

  

Histamine

Released from enterochromaffin-like (ECL) cells in the gastric mucosa and diffuses to the nearby parietal cells.

Stimulates H+ secretion by activating H2 receptors on the parietal cell membrane.

The H2 receptor is coupled to adenylyl cyclase via a Gs protein.

The second messenger for histamine is cAMP.

H2 receptor–blocking drugs, such as cimetidine, inhibit H+ secretion by blocking the stimulatory effect of histamine.

questions.text: A 22-year-old college student presents with small depigmented lesions which have been there for over 2 years now as shown in the image below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The image is suggestive of vitiligo. The pathological basis of vitiligo is the loss of melanocytes.

Vitiligo is a common form of localized depigmentation. It is characterized by milky‐white sharply demarcated macules. It is an acquired condition resulting from the autoimmune destruction of dopa-positive melanocytes in the basal layer of the epidermis.

Vitiligo can begin at any age but in the majority of cases becomes apparent in the third decade. The prevalence is most probably the same in both sexes or a slight female preponderance.

Electron microscopy studies confirm the loss of melanocytes. Wood's lamp examination shows milky-white fluorescence.

Koebner phenomenon defined as the development of lesions at sites of trauma to uninvolved skin of patients with cutaneous diseases is a well‐known phenomenon in vitiligo.

World Vitiligo day is celebrated every year on 25th June to promote understanding and help vitiligo patients avoid discrimination and become more optimistic in life. The theme for the year 2021 is "Embracing Life with Vitiligo".

Other options:

Option A: Melasma is the most common cause of facial melanosis that manifests as hyperpigmented macules on the face. It is exacerbated by sun exposure and oral contraceptive pills. The condition is predominantly seen in females

Option C: Psoriasis: The peak occurrence is between 16 to 22 years and between 57 to 62 years. They usually present with itching and a papulosquamous rash. The lesions are red, and scaly, and have well demarcation from the normal skin. They can also be encircled by a clear peripheral zone which is called the Woronoff ring. They commonly appear in the scalp, trunk, and extensor surfaces of the limbs.

Option D: Dermatitis herpetiformis is a chronic, intensely pruritic, skin condition associated with gluten‐sensitive enteropathy. It typically appears in the 4th decade,  most typically over the extensor surfaces of the elbows, knees, buttocks, and scalp. On examination, multiple erythematous papules and vesicles can be seen over the extensor aspects. They appear symmetrical and heal without scarring. The oral cavity may show mucosal abnormalities and enamel pits.

questions.text: An 8-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents with complaints of fever and rash. The fever was first seen 5 days back and the rash started 2 days back on the face and has progressed to his trunk as shown in the image below. He is diagnosed with measles. The giant cells present in the lymphoid tissue of this patient is_________.
questions.solution:
Warthin-Finkeldey cells are multinucleate giant cells, which are found in the lymphoid tissues of patients with measles.

Measles belong to the paramyxovirus family.

Measles can be divided into four phases:

1) The incubation phase

The incubation phase typically lasts 8 to 12 days after exposure to the virus and does not have any symptoms.

2) The prodromal (catarrhal) phase

The prodromal phase begins at the onset of the first symptoms, which begin gradually and include a fever, a cough, a runny nose, and red eyes. Usually, the fever is the first symptom noticed by parents. The fever rises steadily and may reach maximum temperatures of 103F to 104F.

The runny nose with a profuse watery discharge, nasal congestion, and sneezing becomes prominent. Typically, there is a pronounced cough, which is hoarse, dry, and hacking. Some children may complain of tightening in the chest. The red eyes are characterized by increased tearing, eye pain that may be severe, and sensitivity to light. Other symptoms that are frequently observed during the prodromal phase include fatigue, irritability, a decreased appetite, a headache, abdominal pain, and a dry mouth and throat. Koplik spots are the peculiar spots present on the buccal mucosa and are considered to be a diagnostic/pathognomic feature of measles/rubeola in the prodromal stage.

3) The rash phase

Approximately two to four days after the onset of the symptoms, the rash appears, marking the beginning of the rash phase. The symptoms of the prodromal phase worsen with the onset of the rash, but then begin to decrease in severity. The measles rash is a flat or slightly raised rash and is not itchy. It first appears as irregular spots on the upper forehead or behind the ears and on the neck. Within 24 hours, it progresses to the entire face, head, and neck. Over the next two to four days, the rash extends to the chest, back, and extremities (as seen in the image shown), including the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It remains most prominent on the face, especially on the cheeks.

4) The recovery phase

After four to five days, the rash begins to subside, marking the beginning of the recovery phase. Sometimes, a fine flaking of the skin is noted as the rash fades. About 10 to 14 days after developing the rash, the child is back to a normal level of activity.

The period of communicability is approximately 4 days before and 4 days after the appearance of the rash. Isolation of the patient for a week from the onset of rash more than covers the period of communicability.

Cytopathic effect of measles consist of multinucleate syncytium formation with numerous acidophilic nuclear and cytoplasmic inclusions, as shown in the image below.

questions.text: A child is brought to the pediatric department with characteristic hair as shown in the image. Further examination shows that the child has truncal hypotonia, and failure to thrive. Which of the following enzyme actions will not be affected in this patient?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the image showing an irritable child with kinky colorless, and sparse hair with truncal hypotonia on examination is suggestive of Menke's disease and in this condition, copper is deficient since it is not mobilized from the intestine. Glutathione peroxidase action is not affected since it requires selenium in the form of selenocysteine and not copper.

Copper is a part of numerous enzymes like:

  • Amine oxidases
  • Ferroxidase (ceruloplasmin)
  • Cytochrome c oxidase
  • Superoxide dismutase
  • Tyrosinase (melanin synthesis)
  • Lysyl oxidase (cross-linking in collagen)
  • Dopamine hydroxylase.

It is also a component of ferroportin, which is involved in iron absorption.

Copper deficiency disorders:

Wilson’s disease: It is an autosomal recessive disorder, due to ATP7 B mutation, a gene encoding for copper transporting ATPase in the cells. There is defective biliary copper excretion from liver cells, leading to copper deposits in the liver and brain.

Menke’s (Kinky or Steely) hair syndrome: It is an X-linked recessive condition, where there is a mutation in the ATP7A gene. There is defective copper-binding P-type ATPase and copper is not mobilized from the intestine.

MEDNIK syndrome: A rare multisystem disorder of copper metabolism with features of both Wilson’s and Menke’s disease.

questions.text: What is the Declaration of Oslo related to?
questions.solution:
In 1970, the World Medical Association adopted a resolution on therapeutic abortion known as the Declaration of Oslo.

Option C: Declaration of Helsinki: concerned with human experimentation.

questions.text: A child is found to have the findings shown in the image below, on examination of the lower back. Identify the condition:
questions.solution:
The given image showing a tuft of hair over the lower back is suggestive of spina bifida.

Spina bifida is a general term used for neural tube defects affecting the spinal region and associated with splitting of the vertebral arches. It is characterized by gaps in the vertebral arches and may or may not involve the underlying neural tissue. 

The 3 main types of spina bifida:

  1. Spina bifida occulta - This is the mildest form of spina bifida. The defect in the vertebral arches is covered by the skin. The splits in the vertebrae are so small that the spinal cord does not protrude. The skin at the site of the lesion may be normal. They present only with a tuft of hair over the lower back.
  2. Meningocele - The defect in the vertebra allows the meninges to protrude through the defect.
  3. Myelomeningocele (meningomyelocele) - A defect in the vertebral column allows the spinal cord with the meningeal coverings to protrude. 

Other options:

Option A: Encephalocele refers to the protrusion of intracranial tissue through a midline bony defect.

The two images below show babies with encephalocele, i.e. midline neural tube defects of the cranial end.

Option B: Omphalocele is a congenital midline abdominal wall defect at the base of the umbilical cord insertion, with herniation of the solid abdominal viscera and/or bowel out of the fetal abdomen. The extruded abdominal contents are covered in a sac.

Option C: Rachischisis is the most severe type of neural tube defect, where the entire neural tube fails to close. Rachischisis can occur in the spinal cord or brain regions of the neural tube. The exposed neural tissues often become necrotic.

This condition results from defects in LPL or apo C-II, causing elevated levels of chylomicrons and VLDL, with decreased levels of LDL and HDL. Patients often develop eruptive xanthomas but are not at risk for coronary artery disease. Fibrates are effective in treating patients with type III hyperlipoproteinemia.

questions.text: A 7 year old boy weighing 30kgs is planned for surgical resection of a Wilms tumor. What is the daily maintenance fluid required for this child while he’s NPO?
questions.solution:
The daily maintenance fluid required for a child weighing 30 kg is 1700 ml. 

Bodyweight method for calculating the daily maintenance fluid volume (also known as Holliday-Segar method) is used.

Bodyweight Fluid required per day
0–10 kg 100 mL/kg
11–20 kg 1000 mL + 50 mL/kg for each kg >10 kg
>20 kg 1500 mL + 20 mL/kg for each kg >20 kg

Calculation:

In the question, the weight of the child is given as 30 Kgs.

So, the formula for >20 Kg is used.

1500 mL + (20 mL x weight more than 20 Kgs)

Since the child weight is 30 Kgs, he/she is 10 Kgs more.

Therefore, fluid required is

= 1500 mL + (20 mL x 10)

= 1500 mL + 200 mL

= 1700 mL.

questions.text: Which of the following is given as a part of the standard care along with ORS in children with acute diarrhoea?

Zinc is given as a part of the standard care along with ORS in children with acute diarrhoea

Zinc supplementation is now part of the standard care along with ORS in children with acute diarrhoea. It is helpful in decreasing the severity and duration of diarrhoea and also the risk of persistent diarrhoea.

Vitamin A should therefore be given to all severely malnourished children as a part of the management of SAM and is not a routine standard of care in acute diarrhoea.

Antibiotics are not recommended for routine treatment of acute diarrhoea in children. In acute diarrhoea, antimicrobials are indicated in bacillary dysentery, cholera, amebiasis and giardiasis.

Probiotics contain microorganisms that exert beneficial effects on human health when they colonize the bowel. They have been proposed as adjunctive therapy in the treatment of acute diarrhoea and is not a routine standard of care.

questions.text: Which of the following determines the severity of the Tetralogy of Fallot?
questions.solution:
The determining factor for the severity of TOF (Tetralogy of Fallot) is pulmonary stenosis. Due to pulmonary stenosis, prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow occurs, resulting in severe systemic hypoxia.

TOF is a cyanotic congenital heart disease with the following four components:

  • Obstruction to right ventricular outflow (pulmonary stenosis)
  • Malalignment type of ventricular septal defect (VSD)
  • Dextroposition of the aorta so that it overrides the ventricular septum (overriding of the aorta), and
  • Right ventricular hypertrophy (RVH)

The severity of symptoms depends on the degree of the right ventricular outflow obstruction. In mild degrees, the symptoms become pronounced as the baby grows due to RV infundibular hypertrophy and may present with heart failure. In severe degrees, pulmonary blood flow predominantly depends on the ductus arteriosus. As soon as the duct closes, the baby presents with cyanosis and circulatory collapse in the neonatal period.

The image given below shows the cardinal features seen in TOF:

Clinical features include significant hypercyanotic spells in infants which are characterized by hyperpnea, cyanosis, and gasping followed by syncope. The spells occur most frequently in the morning on initial awakening or after episodes of vigorous crying. These spells are due to a prolonged reduction of pulmonary blood flow resulting in severe systemic hypoxia and metabolic acidosis.

Older children present with exertional dyspnea and assume a squatting position to relieve the dyspneic episode after which the child is able to resume the activity.

The below image shows a boot-shaped cardiac silhouette. This is due to the right ventricular hypertrophy and upward shift of the cardiac apex. The hilar areas and lung fields are relatively oligemic due to diminished pulmonary blood flow. the chest X-ray findings

questions.text: The following image shows the sequence of propulsion of a bolus in the gut by means of peristalsis. Which of the following substances is responsible for the configuration of the segment of the gut marked as 'B'?
questions.solution:
The part of the gut marked by 'B' is the anterograde segment, which is in a state of relaxation. The vasoactive intestinal peptide is responsible for bringing relaxation in this part of the gut.

The above image shows peristalsis. It is a reflex response that is initiated when the gut wall is stretched by the contents of the lumen. It moves in oral to caudal direction.

Stretching of the gut wall releases serotonin and activates the cholinergic neurons present in the myenteric plexus. Cholinergic neurons passing in anterograde direction produce NO and VIP which cause relaxation of a segment of the intestine in front of the bolus. Cholinergic neurons passing in retrograde direction produce substance P and acetylcholine which cause contraction of a segment of the intestine behind the bolus.

NOTE:

In achalasia cardia, there is decreased release of NO and VIP in the distal part of esophagus.

Related Pearl: Mechanism of peristalsis

questions.text: Which of the following is not seen in nutritional rickets?
questions.solution:
Urine calcium: creatinine ratio > 15 is not seen in a case of nutritional rickets. Instead low urine calcium and high urinary phosphate excretion are seen due to stimulation of PTH(parathormone) in vitamin D deficiency(nutritional rickets).

Initially, low calcium levels in the blood stimulate increased PTH secretion from the parathyroid glands that results in bone resorption and increased reabsorption of calcium and increased excretion of phosphorus in the kidneys.

Hence blood calcium levels can be low to normal with low phosphorus levels and high ALP due to increased bone resorption activity.

Note - High urinary calcium excretion is associated with hereditary hypophosphatemic rickets with hypercalciuria.

Nutritional rickets is a skeletal disorder primarily caused by a deficiency in vitamin D, calcium, or phosphorus, or a combination of these nutrients. Rickets typically affect children during periods of rapid growth and bone development. 

25-hydroxy vitamin D level should be measured to diagnose vitamin D deficiency rickets. The initial lab tests in this child should also include serum calcium, phosphorous, alkaline phosphatase (ALP), and parathyroid hormone (PTH). Lab findings reveal decreased calcium and phosphate levels, increased PTH, and ALP.

Treatment with oral vitamin D is preferred. Patients who show no response should be evaluated for other disorders, such as hypophosphatemic rickets, vitamin D-dependent rickets, renal tubular acidosis-associated rickets, and chronic kidney disease-associated rickets.

questions.text: A body was brought in for post-mortem examination, and the following can be seen. What type of wounds are these?
questions.solution:
The given image shows irregular and ragged cut wounds over the palmar surface of the hands and fingers, which is suggestive of defense wounds.

Defense wounds are the wounds that occur as a result of the victim's attempt to save himself from an injury.

It can be active or passive. Active defense wounds occur when the victim tries to grasp the weapon, while passive wounds result when the victim raises the hands, arms, or legs in an attempt to protect the eyes, head, or neck.

The morphology of the wound depends upon the type of weapon and the attack. In a sharp injury due to a single-edged weapon, a single cut may be seen on the palm or the bends of fingers. In the case of a double-edged sharp weapon, cuts are seen on both palm and fingers. The cuts are irregular in-depth and are ragged.

The defense wounds signify homicide, and in females, they often indicate sexual assault. 

Other options:

Options B and C: Antemortem and postmortem wounds are of medicolegal importance while evaluating trauma. They can be differentiated by the following features:

Hemorrhage Arterial type of hemorrhage Venous hemorrhage
Spurting Spurting of blood seen with firmly coagulated blood No spurts and no clotting 
Vital reaction Inflammation and repair seen No signs of inflammation and repair

Option D: Hesitation cuts are a feature of self-inflicted wounds or suicide. It typically appears as multiple, small, and superficial wounds on the skin, at the beginning of an incised wound. The common sites are the throat, wrist, and front of the chest.

questions.text: The condition shown in the given image is due to elevated levels of a particular hormone secreted from a pituitary tumor. This hormone is also seen to be elevated in all of the following, except
questions.solution:
The condition shown in the given image is Cushing's disease caused by a pituitary adenoma secreting adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH). Levels of ACTH decrease at midnight, while asleep.

Cushing's syndrome is caused by hypersecretion of cortisol from the adrenal cortex. When Cushing’s syndrome is secondary to excessive secretion of ACTH by the anterior pituitary, it is referred to as Cushing’s disease.

Any type of physical or mental stress can increase the levels of ACTH to within minutes. This, in turn, elevates cortisol levels up to 20 times normal. Pain stimuli due to physical stress or tissue damage are transmitted to the median eminence of the hypothalamus which secretes corticotropin-releasing factor (CRF). Within minutes, this leads to large quantities of cortisol in the blood.

Mental stress may cause an equally rapid increase in ACTH secretion as a result of increased activity in the limbic system which transmits signals to the hypothalamus.

Prolonged lack of sleep can elevate ACTH levels.

The secretory rates of CRF, ACTH, and cortisol are high in the early morning but low in the late evening. This is a result of a 24-hour cyclical alteration in the signals from the hypothalamus. When a person changes daily sleeping habits, the cycle changes correspondingly.

Related Pearl: Initial Tests for Diagnosing Cushing's Syndrome

These include two steps:

1. Tests to detect hypercortisolism

  • Midnight salivary or serum cortisol (highly sensitive test): The presence of cortisol in the saliva or serum at midnight signifies loss of diurnal variation of cortisol
  • 24-hour urinary free cortisol excretion: Increased three times the normal value
  • Overnight dexamethasone suppression test (DST): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m after overnight exposure to dexamethasone (1 mg given at 11 p.m)
  • Low dose DST (highly specific test): Plasma cortisol >1.8 μg/dL at 8 a.m. on the third day after giving 0.5 mg dexamethasone every 6 hours for 2 days

2. Test to rule out pseudo Cushing's syndrome

  • Low-dose DST + CRH stimulation test: Plasma cortisol levels are increased in true Cushing’s but remain unaffected in pseudo Cushing's. Dexa-induced negative feedback is overcome by CRH in true Cushing’s.

This patient is presenting with an itchy rash and eczematous lesions in sun exposed areas of face and neck 3 days following tetracycline use. Positive photopatch tests points to a diagnosis of photoallergic reaction.

It is a delayed-type IV hypersensitivity reaction with a predilection for photo exposed sites with well‐demarcated margins where the skin is covered by clothing (at the collar and ‘V’ of the neck, on the backs of the hands, and on the ankles). It spares the skin behind the earlobe (Wilkinson’s triangle) since it is a photo-protected site.

Treatment includes photoprotection, withdrawal of the drug, and antihistamines. Topical steroids are used in mild cases, and systemic steroids or methotrexate are used in severe cases.

questions.text: Which of the following glucose transporter is present in skeletal muscles and adipose tissues?
questions.solution:
GLUT-4 is present in skeletal muscle cells and adipose tissues.

Glucose transporters, also referred to as GLUTs, are transport proteins in the cell membrane responsible for the transfer of glucose into the cells by facilitative diffusion. Facilitative diffusion involves the passage of molecules or ions through the cell membrane by them binding chemically to a carrier/ transport protein that is responsible for their movement across the cell membrane.

GLUT-4 is a transport protein present in adipocytes. When there is a rise in blood glucose level, insulin secreted by the pancreatic beta cells binds to its receptors on the plasma membrane of adipocytes. Upon binding of insulin to its receptor, activation of the receptor's tyrosine-kinase domain occurs. This activation starts a protein activation cascade leading to the translocation of GLUT4 to the plasma membrane.

Once translocation occurs and GLUT4 is inserted into the plasma membrane, facilitated diffusion of glucose down its concentration gradient into the cell occurs.

Other options:

Option B: GLUT-2 is found in the liver, pancreatic β cell, small intestine, and kidney. Its function is the rapid uptake or release of glucose.

Option C: GLUT-5 is present in the small intestine and is involved in the absorption of fructose.

Option D: SGLT-1 is a sodium-dependent unidirectional transporter present in the small intestine and kidney that is involved in the active uptake of glucose against a concentration gradient.

questions.text: A 43-year-old woman came in with vomiting and a headache. Upon examination, papilledema was observed. However, her CT scan appeared normal. What could be the underlying cause of her condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features point towards a diagnosis of pseudotumor cerebri or idiopathic intracranial hypertension, and it is caused by vitamin A toxicity.

Toxicity occurs when the accumulation of vitamin A goes beyond the capacity of intracellular binding proteins.

The unbound vitamin A causes membrane lysis and tissue damage. 

Clinical features of hypervitaminosis A:

CNS - Headache, nausea, ataxia, anorexia, increased cerebrospinal fluid pressure aka pseudotumor cerebri.
Liver - Hepatomegaly and hyperlipidemia.
Bones - Thickening of the long bones(Bony exostosis), hypercalcemia, soft tissue calcification.
Dermatological - Dryness, exfoliative dermatitis, alopecia
Teratogenesis - Pregnant women should not ingest excessive quantities as it can cause congenital malformations in the developing fetus. Isotretinoin(13 cis retinoic acid) is a drug which is teratogenic and absolutely contraindicated in pregnancy.

Other options:

Option A: Vitamin B6(Pyridoxine) toxicity causes sensory neuropathy.

Option C: Niacin deficiency causes pellagra, which is characterized by dermatitis, dementia, and diarrhea.

Option D: Vitamin B1 (thiamine) deficiency causes Wernicke's encephalopathy, which is a triad of ophthalmoplegia, global confusion, and ataxia.

Related Pearl: Hypervitaminosis A

Hypervitaminosis A:

  • Vitamin A excess can present as two forms: vitamin A toxicity and carotenaemia.
  •  Hypervitaminosis A results from overconsumption of non‐prescription nutritional supplements, prescription medications containing vitamin A derivatives and foods high in vitamin A.
  • Carotenaemia is a benign disorder caused by excessive β‐carotene intake.
  • In carotenaemia, carotenes are excreted from sebaceous glands and sweat glands, and ultimately deposit in the stratum corneum. This results in carotenoderma.
  • Acute vitamin A toxicity manifests with headaches, vision changes, fatigue, anorexia, nausea, vomiting, myalgias and arthralgias. Weight loss can be observed with chronic intoxication.
  • Individuals with chronic hypervitaminosis A have dry and scaly skin, desquamation, cheilitis, alopecia, follicular hyperkeratosis and hyperpigmentation, associated pseudotumor cerebri and skeletal changes (premature closure of the epiphyses and pathological bone fractures).
  • Prognosis:
    • Vitamin A toxicity: discontinuation of vitamin A leads to resolution of almost all symptoms of vitamin A toxicity, with the exception of cirrhosis and sequelae related to pseudotumour cerebri.
    • Carotenaemia: Excellent prognosis with no clear long‐term adverse effects. Pigmentary changes resolve within weeks to months of decreasing β‐carotene intake.

questions.text: A baby was brought to the clinic with symptoms of diarrhea, failure to thrive, and hair loss. On examination, the following findings are noted. Identify the mineral deficiency leading to this condition.
questions.solution:

The traditional 5 F's - flies, fingers, fomites, food, and fluids can be used to remember the modes of indirect transmission. Some infectious agents are able to survive in the external environment while maintaining their basic properties of virulence. This is a  requirement for this indirect transmission. 

An important distinction has to be drawn between droplet nuclei infection and droplet infection. The main difference between airborne droplet nuclei and droplet transmission is in the size of infected/contagious particles and whether proximity is required for transmission.

Droplet nuclei/residue from evaporated droplets containing infective microorganisms can result in airborne transmission. The size of these droplet nuclei is <5 μm in diameter, and they can remain suspended in the air for significant periods of time, allowing them to be transmitted over distances >1 m.  There's no need for close proximity or contact. Diseases like chickenpox, measles, tuberculosis, and influenza can spread through airborne transmission.

Droplet transmission occurs when one coughs or sneezes, and contagious droplets from the infected person travel shortly in the air and directly comes in contact with another person's conjunctiva, mouth, or nasal mucosa. The particle size here is >5 μm in diameter. Transmission here requires close proximity and direct contact. Examples of diseases spread via this route include the common cold, diphtheria, and whooping cough.

questions.text: In a civil negligence case against a doctor who bears the onus of proof?

questions.solution:
In case of a civil negligence against a doctor, the burden of proof is on the patient.

The question of civil negligence arises when a suit is filed in a civil court:

  • By a patient or his/her relatives against the doctor for getting compensation from the doctor if he/she has suffered an injury due to the doctor's negligence.
  • By a doctor against the patient or his/her relatives to collect the fees, the payment of which has been refused due to alleged professional negligence by the doctor.

In either case, the patient has to prove that the doctor has committed professional negligence. To prove negligence, all the following four elements must be present:

  • Duty: A duty of care by the doctor must exist.
  • Dereliction: The physician must maintain the standard of a 'prudent physician' under similar circumstances. If the physician fails to maintain the standard of care, it is called dereliction.
  • Direct causation: The negligent act or omission must directly cause the injury without any intervening cause.
  • Damage: The negligent act must cause damage of a type that would have been foreseen by a reasonable physician.

questions.text: A 17-year-old boy presented with intussusception and was taken up for surgery. He was found to have multiple polyps. The resected section was sent for histopathology and the whole mount image of the specimen is given below. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The given clinical feature of intussusception and multiple polyps and the histologic picture showing an arborizing pattern of connective tissue, smooth muscle, lamina propria, and glands are suggestive of Peutz–Jeghers Syndrome, which is a type of hamartomatous polyp of the small intestine.

It is an autosomal dominant condition characterized by hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract and melanosis of the mouth and the lips. 

Clinical features:

  • Hamartomatous polyps of the intestinal tract
  • Hyperpigmentation of the buccal mucosa, lips, perianal skin, and digits
  • Increased (2% to 10%) risk for cancer of the intestinal tract, with cancers reported throughout the intestinal tract, from the stomach to the rectum.
  • Increased risk for extraintestinal malig­nant neoplasms, including cancer of the breast, ovary, cervix, fallopian tubes, thyroid, lung, gallbladder, bile ducts, pancreas, and testicles.

Management:

  • Surgery is indicated in cases where there is bleeding, obstruction, intussusception, or adenomatous changes of the polyp.
  • If surgery is done for these indications attempts should be made to remove as much as polyps as possible. 
  • Regular screening with endoscopic studies should be done due to the increased risk of malignancies.
  • Screening of other malignancies like breast and cervix are also important.

Other options

Option A: Tubulovillous adenoma are a mixture of tubular and villous adenomas. They consist of small, pedunculated polyps composed of rounded or tubular glands and larger, sessile polyps which are covered by slender villi. These adenomas are characterized microscopically by the presence of epithelial dysplasia the hallmarks of which are nuclear hyperchromasia, elongation and stratification. 

Option C: Adenocarcinoma presents with occult bleeding, changes in bowel habits, or cramping and left lower quadrant discomfort. Morphologically, they present as polypoid, exophytic masses or annular lesions that produce ‘napkin-ring’ construction and luminal narrowing. Microscopically, these tumours consist of tall columnar cells with elongated, hyperchromatic nuclei and necrotic debris in the gland lumen.

Option D: Hyperplastic polyp most commonly found in the left colon are smooth, nodular protrusions of the mucosa, often on the crests of mucosal folds. Histologically, they are composed of mature goblet and absorptive cells with a serrated surface architecture.

questions.text: A screening test gave positive results in 60% of the diseased individuals and 20% of the healthy individuals. Calculate the specificity for this test.
questions.solution:
The specificity of a test from the given information can be calculated as 0.8.

60% of individuals having the disease came out to be positive. So for 100 diseased individuals, 60 are True positives and 40 are False negatives.

20% of the individuals not having the disease came out to be positive. so for 100 healthy individuals, 20 are False positives and 80 are true negatives.

The specificity of a test is given by those who are healthy(do not have the disease) and test negative (true negatives) out of the total healthy population. So the specificity = TN divided by TN+FP, i.e 80/100= 0.8

The sensitivity of a test is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total diseased population. Here Sensitivity= TP/TP+FN = 60/100=0.6

The test's positive predictive value is given by those who have the disease and test positive (true positives) out of the total positive population. Here PPV= TP/TP+FP = 60/80=0.75

The negative predictive value of the test is given by those who do not have the disease and test negative (true negatives) out of the total negative population. NPV here= TN/TN+FN = 80/120=0.67

questions.text: A 3-month-old infant who was born at term was presented with complaints of lethargy and poor feeding. On examination, the infant had a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, and protruding tongue, as shown below. The lower limb x-ray revealed an absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphysis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the image are suggestive of congenital hypothyroidism.

The clinical features of congenital hypothyroidism include a puffy face, enlarged fontanelles, protruding tongue, prolonged jaundice, lethargy, and a history of poor feeding. The absence of distal femoral and proximal tibial epiphyses denotes the onset of congenital hypothyroidism. These epiphyses are normally present at birth.

Congenital hypothyroidism is the most common preventable cause of intellectual disability. Thyroid dysgenesis is the most common cause of congenital hypothyroidism in India accounting for about 75% of all cases.

Congenital hypothyroidism is mostly asymptomatic at birth and is detected mainly by the neonatal screening of TSH levels in the first few weeks of life. Clinical features present after maternal thyroxine wanes.

Screening is usually done on day 2-day 4 postnatally, and usually, dried blood samples are used for this. The most commonly used strategy is screening for TSH first, as they have higher sensitivity compared to the T4-based screening.

In untreated hypothyroidism, as the child grows older, there is a discrepancy between chronological age and osseous development. Epiphyseal dysgenesis wherein there are multiple foci of ossification in the epiphyses, is common. X-rays of the skull reveal large fontanelles, wide sutures, and intersutural (wormian) bones. Radiotracer uptake study with radioactive iodine or technetium should be done as soon as primary congenital hypothyroidism is diagnosed.

Treatment with levothyroxine should be started within 2 weeks in order to maintain normal cognitive and physical development. Thyroxine of dose 10-15 μg/kg/day should be started and adjusted to achieve the normal free T4 range. TSH may be elevated up to 2 years of age with a reset of the hypothalamic-pituitary axis. 

Other options:

Option A- Down’s syndrome also presents with developmental delay and hypothyroidism. They have characteristic facial features such as a flat face, depressed nasal bridge, upslanting palpebral fissures, and a single palmar crease. Option B-  Congenital rickets is a rare condition resulting from severe maternal vitamin D deficiency and can present with symptomatic hypocalcemia, intrauterine growth retardation, decreased bone ossification along with classic rachitic changes.

Option D- Hurler's syndrome is a mucopolysaccharidosis which may present after 6 months with hepatosplenomegaly, coarse facial features, corneal clouding, large tongue, prominent forehead, joint stiffness, short stature, and skeletal dysplasia.

questions.text: Depth of inspiration is increased by_____

choices.text: Ventral group of neurons in medulla

questions.solution:
Depth of inspiration is increased by the apneustic center.

The apneustic centre sends signals to prevent switching off of inspiration maintained by the dorsal respiratory group of neurons, thereby increasing depth of inspiration. 

In contrast to this, the pneumotaxic center primarily limits inspiration by controlling the "switch off" point of the inspiratory ramp signal. 

A note on inspiratory ramp signal:

The neural signals transmitted to the inspiratory muscle, mainly the diaphragm, is not the instantaneous burst of action potentials. Instead, it begins weakly and increases steadily in a ramped manner. The advantage of the ramp is that it causes a steady increase in the volume of the lungs during inspiration, rather than inspiratory gasps.

Control of the limiting point at which the ramp suddenly ceases is the mechanism by which the respiratory centers control depth and rate of respiration.

questions.text: A woman presents to the dermatology OPD with increased loss of hair for the past 4 months. She had COVID-19 infection 6 months back. Blood investigations reveal iron deficiency anemia. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of a female patient presenting with increased hair loss, a history of COVID-19 infection, and blood investigations revealing iron deficiency anemia likely has telogen effluvium. 

Telogen effluvium is a type of non-scarring alopecia characterized by the increased shedding of normal hair. This occurs because of the premature termination of the anagen phase of the hair cycle. Telogen effluvium can manifest as either acute or chronic.

Acute telogen effluvium typically occurs 2-3 months after a stressful event, such as surgery, infection, starvation, or hemorrhage. Additionally, hormonal fluctuations during the postpartum period, known as telogen gravidarum, can also trigger this condition. Although telogen effluvium can lead to a widespread reduction in hair density, it never progresses to total baldness. This condition tends to resolve on its own.

Chronic telogen effluvium is characterized by persistent diffuse shedding of telogen hair lasting more than 6 months. Common causes include thyroid disorders, iron-deficiency anemia, and malnutrition.

Other options:

Option B: Anagen effluvium arises from the disruption of the anagen phase of the hair cycle, primarily occurring after chemotherapy. 

Option C: Alopecia areata is a chronic, inflammatory, non-scarring form of hair loss characterized by the appearance of well-defined, smooth patches on the scalp.

Option D: Scarring alopecia is associated with conditions like lichen planus, sarcoidosis, connective tissue diseases (eg. SLE), and tinea capitis. It is characterized by irregular areas of hair loss with associated scarring.

questions.text: What is the best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth?
questions.solution:
The best indicator to evaluate obstetric and neonatal care given before and around the time of birth is perinatal mortality rate.

Perinatal mortality includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths. Hence it is a better indicator of obstetric and neonatal care.

Related Pearl: Perinatal Mortality Rate

  • The term ‘perinatal mortality’ includes both late fetal death (stillbirths) and early neonatal deaths.
  • Babies chosen for inclusion in perinatal statistics should be above a minimum birth weight (1000g at birth). If the birth weight is not available, a gestation period of at least 28 weeks should be used (as the weight at 28 weeks corresponds to 1000g). If both are not available, then crown to heel length of at least 35cm should be used.
  • Generally, the PMR = Late fetal deaths and early neonatal deaths weighing over 1000g at birth x 1000/Total births(live+dead) weighing over 1000g at birth.
  • The PMR is the yard-stick of obstetric and pediatric care before and around the time of birth.
  • The PMR of India (2016) is 24 per 1000 births.
  • The main causes of perinatal mortality are intrauterine and birth asphyxia, low birth weight, birth trauma, and intrauterine/neonatal infections.

Please note that the actual perinatal period commences from the 22nd week of life, but at that time the fetus weighs only about 500g.

Therefore, only for statistical calculations and international comparisons, to calculate the perinatal mortality rate, the period from the 28th week of life is taken, as then the baby weighs about 1000g. As mentioned, babies included in the perinatal statistics must weigh above 1000g.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presented with low-grade fever, headache, and mild upper respiratory tract infection. He also developed an erythematous rash on the cheek which progressed to the extremities the following day as shown below. The agent responsible for this condition has ________

questions.text: You were posted for screening of deafness in school children under your primary health center. Which type of screening is done in this scenario?
questions.solution:
The type of screening done for deafness in school children is prescriptive screening. 

Prescriptive screening is done for case detection. People are examined primarily for their own benefit. It may lead to the early identification of an unrecognized disease. Hence, appropriate treatment can be initiated immediately to decline the disease progression.

Screening is initiated by medical and public health personnel and is not requested by a patient. Examples of prescriptive screening are:

  • Screening of hemolytic disease in newborns
  • Screening of infants for phenylketonuria
  • Screening of bacteriuria in pregnancy

Other options:

Option A - Prospective screening is done for disease control. People are screened for the benefit of others. It may lead to an early diagnosis and permit more effective treatment. It also reduces the spread of infectious diseases in the community. Hence, reduces mortality associated with the disease. Examples of prospective screening are:

  • Screening of immigrants from infectious diseases such as tuberculosis and syphilis to protect the citizens
  • Screening for streptococcal infection to prevent rheumatic fever

Option B - Multiphasic screening is the application of two or more screening tests in combination, to a large population at one time. It is not cost-effective and has shown no benefit in reducing the morbidity and mortality of the population.

Option D - Selective screening is done in high-risk groups. It is one of the most effective screening tests.

Example: Screening for diabetes in the other members of a family for a detected diabetes case since these diseases get aggregated in families.

questions.text: A lethargic infant was presented with vomiting and irritability. He was diagnosed with an X-linked recessive disorder due to the deficiency of ornithine transcarbamoylase. What is the likely disorder?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario with a deficiency in enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase is likely to have a diagnosis of type 2 hyperammonemia inherited in an X-linked recessive manner.

In the urea cycle, the enzyme ornithine transcarbamoylase catalyzes the condensation of carbamoyl phosphate with ornithine to form citrulline. The deficiency of this enzyme leads to the accumulation of carbamoyl phosphate leading to elevated levels of glutamine in the blood, urine, and cerebrospinal fluid. 

Infants present with vomiting, irritability, lethargy, hypothermia, and apnea due to high ammonia levels in the plasma. Mothers also have an aversion to protein-rich foods. 

Urea cycle disorders are all characterized by hyperammonemia, encephalopathy, and respiratory alkalosis. This is due to an accumulation of the precursors of urea namely ammonia, and glutamine.

The enzymes involved in the urea cycle with their related disorders are given below:

  1. Carbamoyl-phosphate synthetase (CPS) 1 deficiency (hyperammonemia type 1) - rare and characterized by severe hyperammonemia.
  2. Ornithine transporter deficiency (HHH syndrome) - is characterized by hyperornithinemia, hyperammonemia, and homocitrullinuria.
  3. Ornithine transcarbamylase (OTC) deficiency (hyperammonemia type 2) - is inherited as an X-linked trait. Characterized by hyperammonemia and elevated glutamine levels in blood and CSF.
  4. Argininosuccinate synthetase deficiency - is characterized by increased citrulline, citrullinuria, and hyperammonemia.
  5. Argininosuccinate lyase deficiency- leads to argininosuccinic acidemia and metabolic acidosis. Hyperammonemia is less severe and argininosuccinate is found in urine and CSF.
  6. Arginase deficiency- mild variety. Characterized by hyperargininemia and argininuria.

Clinical features of urea cycle disorders are common to all and include vomiting, avoidance of high-protein foods, intermittent ataxia, irritability, lethargy, and severe mental retardation. 

Long terms treatment consists of a protein-restricted diet.

Related Pearl: Urea Cycle and its disorders

questions.text: In which of the following conditions is a false positive hydrostatic test in fetus seen?
questions.solution:
The hydrostatic test is falsely positive in the case of putrefied fetus.

Hydrostatic test is done to determine whether the newborn has respired or not. It is also known as floatation test/ Breslau’s first life test/ Raygat’s test.

If the lung pieces float in water, it means that respiration has taken place, indicating a live birth. If the pieces sink, respiration has not taken place, which means it is stillborn.

An unrespired lung (stillbirth) may float, giving a false positive test, due to gases of decomposition, as seen in putrefaction. 

Related Pearl: Hydrostatic Test/Floatation Test/Raygat's Test

It is based on the lung changes in a fetus after respiration.

Principle: Respired air remains in the lungs as residual air which cannot be removed after death. Hence lung floats in water.

False-negative test in:

  • Atelectasis
  • Pulmonary edema
  • Pneumonia
  • Congenital syphilis
  • Air absorbed from air passages if circulation continued for long time after cessation of respiration
  • More air exhaled from the lungs compared to air entering during inspiration
  • Obstruction by alveolar duct membrane

False-positive test in:

  • Putrefied foetus
  • Artificial inflation

Hydrostatic test is not required when:

  • Fetus is monstrous
  • Fetus is macerated or mummified
  • Fetus is born before 180 days of gestation
  • Stomach contains milk
  • Umbilical cord has separated and scar has been formed

questions.text: The given image is a dissected specimen of the posterior surface of the knee. What is the nature of the gait associated with damage to the structure marked in the image below?
questions.solution:
The structure marked is the common peroneal nerve. Damage to it would result in a high stepping gait.

The common peroneal nerve descends down obliquely along the lateral side of the popliteal fossa, until the fibular head. It lies medial to the biceps femoris. The common peroneal nerve is a component of the sciatic nerve. In the posterior thigh, it supplies the short head of the biceps femoris. It curves around the neck of the fibula deep to the peroneus longus and divides into superficial and deep peroneal nerves.

  • The superficial peroneal nerve innervates peroneus longus and peroneus brevis, which are the evertors of the foot, and to the skin over the dorsal area of the foot, except for the first webspace and lateral side of the little toe.
  • The deep peroneal nerve innervates all muscles of the anterior compartment, which are the dorsiflexors of the foot, extensor digitorum brevis, first two dorsal interossei muscles, and skin between the great and second toes.

Common peroneal nerve is more prone to injury as it lies superficial at the level of the lateral aspect of the neck of the fibula. The clinical features of common peroneal nerve injury include the following:

  • Foot drop (image below shows a foot drop in the right calf) leading to high stepping gait.
  • Weakness or paralysis of ankle dorsiflexion, toe extension, and eversion
  • A diminished sensation on the dorsum of the foot including the first dorsal web space
  • Plantar flexion, inversion, and ankle reflex are preserved

Other options:

  • Cautious gait is seen in persons with spinal TB; they will walk carefully with short steps to avoid pain resulting from movement.
  • Wide-stepping gait is a broad-based unstable gait and is indicative of cerebellar dysfunction.
  • Waddling gait is seen in developmental dysplasia of the hip and in proximal muscle weakness.

questions.text: A statistician collects data regarding life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income of the population. Which among the following is most likely being calculated by the statistician?
questions.solution:
The index that is calculated using the given indicators such as life expectancy at birth, mean and expected years of schooling, and the per capita income is the Human Developmental Index (HDI).

Human Development Index (HDI) is defined as a composite index focusing on three basic dimensions of human development. It assesses abilities 

  • To lead a healthy long life - measured by life expectancy at birth
  • To acquire knowledge- measured by mean years of schooling
  • To achieve a decent standard of living- measured by gross national income per capita

Hence the 3 dimension indices used to calculate the human development index are as follows life expectancy index, education index, and gross national index. 

Other options:

Option A- Physical Quality of Life Index (PQLI) uses three indicators which include infant mortality, life expectancy at age one, and literacy rate.

Option B- Multidimensional Poverty Index (MPI) - It is an international measure of acute multidimensional poverty by capturing the acute deprivations in health, education, and living standards that a person faces simultaneously. It is assessed using 3 dimensions and 10 indicators which are as follows:

  1. Health - Nutrition and child mortality
  2. Education- Years of schooling and school attendance
  3. Standard of living - 
    • Cooking fuel
    • Sanitation
    • Drinking water
    • Electricity
    • Housing
    • Assets

Option C- Disability-adjusted life years (DALY): It is the amount of time lost due to ill health. It is expressed as the number of years lost due to ill-health, disability, or early death. The components of DALY are:

  • Years of life lost due to premature death
  • Years lived with disability (YLD)
  • Years lived in a state less than full health

questions.text: Which of the following ganglion innervates the parasympathetic part of the lacrimal gland?
questions.solution:
The pterygopalatine ganglion (also known as Meckel's ganglion) supplies the lacrimal glands and palatal glands.

Parasympathetic (secretomotor) supply to the lacrimal gland, glands of the nasal mucosa and palate travel in the nerve of the pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve) and reach the pterygopalatine ganglion where they relay before reaching the target.

They also supply the blood vessels of the nose and cause vasodilation.

Sympathetic nerve fibers come from the upper two thoracic segments of the spinal cord, pass through the superior cervical ganglion, travel in the deep petrosal nerve, and join the parasympathetic fibers of the greater petrosal nerve to form the nerve of the pterygoid canal (Vidian nerve). They reach the nasal cavity without relaying in the sphenopalatine ganglion. Their stimulation causes vasoconstriction.

Other options:

Option A: The otic ganglion supplies the parotid gland.

Option C: The autonomic fibers of the Edinger–Westphal nucleus, which pass through the ciliary ganglion supply the pupillary reflexes.  

Option D: The submandibular ganglion supplies the submandibular glands and sublingual glands.

questions.text: A 3-year-old child presents with muscle weakness, vomiting, and seizures accompanied by focal neurological deficits. Her developmental milestones were normal during the previous visits. Laboratory tests show lactic acidosis and microscopic findings of muscle biopsy are shown below.  What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario shows a child who had normal development previously and then presenting with symptoms of lactic acidosis and stroke(seizures with focal neurological deficits), suggestive of MELAS [mitochondrial encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke] .

The microscopy of muscle biopsy with modified Gomori trichrome staining shows ragged red fibers (arrowhead). Based on these features, the child is probably suffering from MELAS, which is a mitochondrial inherited condition due to complex I or complex IV deficiency.

Mitochondrial proteins and tRNAs may be encoded by either the nuclear genome or the mitochondrial genome (mtDNA). While mutations in nuclear mitochondrial genes follow Mendelian inheritance patterns, mutations in mtDNA are maternally inherited, since all of the mitochondria in the embryo are contributed by the oocyte.

Mitochondrial encephalomyopathy with lactic acidosis and stroke-like episodes (MELAS)
Kearns–Sayre syndrome, characterized by ophthalmoplegia
Pigmentary degeneration of the retina and complete heart block
Myoclonic epilepsy with ragged red fibers
Leber hereditary optic neuropathy are other examples of mitochondrial disease caused by point mutations in mtDNA.

Many mitochondrial disorders such as subacute necrotizing encephalopathy (Leigh syndrome) are remarkably heterogeneous genetically and may be caused by mutations in either mtDNA or the nuclear genome.
