questions.text: Which of the following molecular motors is mainly responsible for the ciliary movement?
questions.solution:
The interaction of the axonemal dynein with the microtubules is responsible for the ciliary movement.

Molecular motors are ATPases that move proteins, organelles, and other cellular components collectively referred to as 'cargo' to various parts of the cell. They convert the energy of ATP into movement along the cytoskeleton, taking their cargo with them. There are three superfamilies of molecular motors, which include dynein, kinesin and myosin.

Dyneins:

  • They have two heads, with their neckpieces embedded in a complex of proteins.
  • Cytoplasmic dyneins are similar to conventional kinesin, except they move particles and membranes to the minus (–) end of the microtubules.
  • Axonemal dyneins are present with the axonemes of the cilia. An axoneme consists of a unique arrangement of nine outer microtubule doublets and two inner microtubules ("9+2" arrangement). The coordinated dynein–microtubule interactions within the axoneme are responsible for the ciliary and sperm movement.

Kinesin:

  • The conventional form of kinesin is a double-headed molecule that moves its cargo toward the plus (“+”) ends of microtubules.
  • Some kinesins are associated with mitosis and meiosis.
  • Other kinesins perform different functions, and may also move cargo to the minus (“–”) end of microtubules.

Myosins:

  • There are about 18 classes of myosins.
  • The heads of some myosin molecules (myosin II) bind to actin and produce motion by bending their neck regions.
  • Some myosin molecules (myosin V) may move the cargo, by walking along microfilaments, one head after the other.

Other options:

Option C: Dynamin is a GTPase responsible for clathrin-mediated endocytosis.

questions.text: An elderly male patient who underwent a kidney transplant 10 years back is on immunosuppressive therapy. He gives a history of cough and dyspnea for the past 1 week, and the sputum microscopy shows gram-positive budding yeasts cells and pseudohyphae. What is the likely diagnosis?

choices.text: Information is not enough for the diagnosis

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario along with microscopy showing gram-positive budding yeasts cells and pseudohyphae is suggestive of invasive candidiasis.

Candida is the most common cause of opportunistic mycoses in the world. Immunocompromised individuals are at an increased risk of systemic candidiasis, which includes candidal endocarditis and urinary tract infections.

The most common species implicated in candidal infections are C. albicans, C. parapsilosis, and C. glabrata. Clinically, infection with candida can present as cutaneous & mucosal candidiasis, systemic candidiasis, or rarely, as chronic mucocutaneous candidiasis.

Cutaneous and mucosal infections manifest as thrush affecting the tongue, lips, gums, and palate. It is seen as a patchy to confluent whitish pseudomembranous lesion and is commonly associated with AIDS. Candida may also invade the vaginal mucosa leading to vulvovaginitis, and the nails, and around the nail plate leading to onychomycosis.

Morphologically, they are yeast-like fungi. They exist as yeast and pseudohyphae (Shown in the image below). It appears as budding gram-positive cells on wet films and smears. Mycelial forms suggest colonization. Candida albicans form chlamydospores on corn meal agar.

When colonies of Candida albicans are inoculated in serum, the yeast cells start to form elongations called germ tubes within 2 hours, when kept at 37 °C. The image below shows germ tube formation, also known as the Reynolds Braude phenomenon, seen in Candida albicans.

Related Pearl: Classification of fungus based on morphology

Fungi are classified into 4 types based on their morphology:

  • Yeast
  • Yeast-like
  • Molds
  • Dimorphic fungi

Yeast:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding
  • Oval to round forms
  • Example: Cryptococcus, Saccharomyces.

 

Yeast like:

  • Unicellular fungi
  • Reproduces by budding or binary fission
  • Spherical or oval forms
  • Pseudohyphae may be seen.
  • Example: Candida, Malassezia furfur.

 

Molds/filamentous fungi:

  • Have hyphae which may be septate or aseptate
  • Aseptate or coenocytic hyphae – Rhizopus, mucor, Lichtheimia.
  • Septate hyphae – Penicillium, Dermatophytes, Aspergillus, fusarium.

 

Dimorphic fungi

  • Filamentous forms in the culture at 220C – 250C and in the environment.
  • Yeast form in the culture at 370C and in tissues.
  • Examples – Histoplasma capsulatum, Blastomyces dermatitidis, Coccidioides immitis, Paracoccidioides brasiliensis, Talaromyces marneffei, Sporothrix schenckii.

questions.text: A patient with sciatica was found to have inflammation of the muscle marked below. Identify it.
questions.solution:
The marked muscle is the piriformis muscle. 

  • Origin:
    • The anterior surface of the sacrum
    • The posterior inferior iliac spine
    • The capsule of the sacroiliac joint
    • Sacrotuberous ligament
  • Insertion - greater trochanter of the femur.
  • Action -  lateral rotation of the thigh in extension and abduction of the thigh in the flexed position

The muscle forms the posterolateral wall of the pelvic cavity. The sciatic nerve is closely related to the muscle and it passes through the muscle fibres or above the muscle.

Clinical significance:

Piriformis syndrome is a clinical condition characterized by the compression of the sciatic nerve by the piriformis muscle. This can occur due to inflammation of the piriformis muscle. The patient will present with pain along the distribution of the sciatic nerve which is also known as sciatica.

questions.text: An epidemiologist plans to conduct a prospective study instead of a retrospective study. Which of the following disadvantages does he aim to eliminate by conducting this study?
questions.solution:
Recall bias can be eliminated in a prospective study.

Memory or recall bias: When cases and controls are asked questions about their past history, it may be more likely for the cases to recall the existence of certain events or factors, than the controls who are healthy persons. For example, those who have had a myocardial infarction might be more likely to remember and recall certain habits or events than those who have not. Thus cases may have a different recall of past events than controls.

Prospective studies begin in the present and continue into future. Hence there will be minimal change for recall bias.

Related Pearl: Bias in Epidemiological Studies

  • Bias due to confounding: It can be removed by matching.
  • Memory or recall bias as cases and controls may not be able to recall specifics about their history.
  • Selection bias: Cases and controls may not be representative of the population or there may be systematic differences between both.
  • Berkesonian bias: This type of selection bias occurs in hospital cases and controls as the admission rates for people with different diseases may differ.
  • Interviewer’s bias: If the interviewer knows the hypothesis and who the cases are, he/she may interview the cases more thoroughly than the controls. It can be eliminated by double blinding.
  • Neyman’s bias or prevalence-incidence bias: It is due to the selective survival in prevalent cases usually seen in fatal diseases. For example, a case-control study is carried out to study the relation between tobacco smoking and acute myocardial infarction (AMI), being cases interviewed one week after the coronary attack. If smoker patients with AMI die more frequently, the living cases will show lower frequency of smoking, undervaluing the association between smoking and AMI. It has been shown that the bias occurs only if the risk factor influences mortality from the disease being studied.

Related Pearl: Blinding in Epidemiology

  • Blinding is done in epidemiology to reduce the possibility of bias.
  • Types
    • In single blind trials, only the participants or group members are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In double blind trials, both the group members and the observers are not aware of the group allocation.
    • In triple blind trials, the group members, the observers and the analyzers are unaware of the group allocation.
  • The most commonly used type of blinding is double blinding.

questions.text: A patient with a category-II dog bite presents to the trauma center on 2nd September 2022. After the local wound management, the patient has been prescribed a schedule for rabies vaccine administration. He marks the days when he is supposed to take the vaccine in a calendar as shown below.  Which regimen is likely prescribed to the patient? What is the route of administration in this case?
questions.solution:
The regimen prescribed here is the Essen regimen which is intramuscular.

Post-exposure prophylaxis regimen for rabies:

Intramuscular regimen: In this regimen, 1 ml or 0.5 ml of vaccine is injected into the deltoid in patients with category II and III wounds.

  • Essen regimen: It is a 5-dose regimen in which 1 dose of vaccine is given on days 0, 3, 7, 14, and 28 each. (1,1,1,1,1)
  • Thai red cross regimen: It is a 4-dose multisite regimen in which 2 doses of vaccine are given on day 0, 3, 7, 28 each. (2-2-2-0-2)

Intradermal regimen: In this regimen, 0.1 ml of injection is given at 2 sites on days 0, 3, 7, and 28 each.

The following measures should be taken immediately to stop the contraction of rabies:

  • Cleansing - The most important step in the prevention of rabies is washing the affected area with plenty of soap and water under a running tap for 15 minutes. This is a standard procedure that minimizes the contraction of rabies.
  • Chemical treatment - Irrigation of the wound should then be done with virucidal agents like alcohol, tincture, 0.01% solution of aqueous iodine, or povidone-iodine. Even irrigating the wound with cetrimide + chlorhexidine solution can be done. This process eliminates the residual virus in the wound.
  • Suturing - Bite wounds are not sutured generally. If suturing is necessary, it is done after 24-48 hours under the cover of local infiltration of the rabies immunoglobulin which is generally done in category III wounds.
  • Other measures - Local antibiotics and tetanus toxoid should be given.

According to the Ministry of Health and Family Welfare, GOI:

Individuals with WHO category II or III exposures should receive PEP without delay.

One ID dose is 0.1 mL of vaccine and one IM dose is an entire vial of vaccine, irrespective of the vial size.

Should a vaccine dose be delayed for any reason, the PEP schedule should be resumed (not restarted).

Rabies Immunoglobulin(RIG): 

  • RIG provides a passive immunization and is administered only once, as soon as possible after the initiation of PEP and not beyond 7 days after the first dose of vaccine.
  • Vaccines should never be withheld regardless of the availability of RIG.
  • Max dose: hRIG - 20IU/kg , eRIG - 40IU/kg body weight.
  • WHO has recommended the use of Monoclonal Antibodies (mAb) as a “cocktail” containing at least two antibodies against RABV, as alternatives for RIGs in PEP.
  • All of the rabies immunoglobulin, or as much as anatomically possible (but avoiding possible compartment syndrome), should be administered into or around the wound site or sites. The remaining immunoglobulin, if any, should be injected intramuscularly at a site distant from the site of vaccine administration. Rabies immunoglobulin may be diluted to a volume sufficient for all wounds to be effectively and safely infiltrated.
  • Prioritization of RIG allocation: Multiple bites>Deep wounds>Bites to head, neck, and hands>Patients with severe immunodeficiency>The biting animal is confirmed or probable rabies>Bites, scratches, and exposure of mucous membranes caused by a bat.

(PrEP)Pre-exposure prophylaxis

  • PrEP considered in remote, rabies-endemic areas where access to PEP is difficult, the dog bite incidence is >5% per year or vampire bat rabies are known to be present.
  • Pre-exposure rabies vaccination consists of three intramuscular (IM) or intradermal (ID) doses are given on days 0, 7, and 21 or 28. For adults, the vaccine should always be administered in the deltoid area of the arm; for young children (under 1 year of age), the anterolateral area of the thigh is recommended. Rabies vaccine should never be administered in the gluteal area. Administration in this manner will result in lower neutralizing antibody titers.
  • For exposed or re-exposed patients who can document previous complete PrEP or PEP the following guidelines would be applicable:
    • Proper wound management should be done.
    • There is no need for the administration of RIG.
    • One site ID or IM vaccine administration on days 0 and 3.
    Only adequate wound washing would be required in case of re-exposure where the animal bite victim has documented proof of complete PEP or PrEP within the last three months.
    • People who have previously received full post-exposure treatment with neural tissue vaccines (NTV) or vaccine of unproven potency or cannot document complete PEP or PrEP treatment should be treated as a fresh case and given full PEP.

questions.text: A drug with a half-life of 8 hours is administered orally three times a day. How long will it take for the plasma concentration to reach a steady state?
questions.solution:
The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives. As the half-life of the given drug is 8 hours, it will take 32-40 hours to reach a steady state. Hence, 36 hours will be the most appropriate answer.

Steady-state: The amount of drug administered is equal to the amount of drug eliminated within one dosing interval resulting in a plateau or constant drug plasma concentration, with the plasma concentration fluctuating between a minimum and maximum.

The time taken to reach steady-state plasma concentration is 4-5 half-lives.

Drugs with a shorter half-life reach a steady state rapidly, whereas drugs with a longer half-life take days to weeks to attain a steady state.

Steady-state concentration (Css) = F x Dosing rate/ CL

  • where the dosing rate is the dose per time interval and is dose/T
  • F is the fractional bioavailability, CL is clearance.

In the case of intravenous infusion,

Steady-state concentration (Css) = Rate of infusion/ CL

Pharmacokinetics of repeated drug dosing:

Plasma concentration of the drug will increase, reach a maximum, and decline after the first dose. A second dose will be administered before the first dose is eliminated. Consequently, the plasma concentration resulting from the second dose will be higher than from the first dose.

This increase in plasma concentration of the drug will occur continuously on repeated dosing (drug accumulation occurs) until a steady state at which drug elimination is equal to drug administration is reached. This is known as the plateau principle of drug accumulation.

questions.text: A young man with chronic bacterial prostatitis was treated with cotrimoxazole. During treatment, he developed malaise, jaundice, abdominal pain, and dark urine. His blood picture is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in the above case scenario is glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD) deficiency.

The clinical features are suggestive of an acute hemolytic reaction following the administration of cotrimoxazole. A hemolytic attack starts with abrupt onset of malaise, weakness, and abdominal or lumbar pain. After an interval of several hours to 2–3 days, the patient develops jaundice and often dark urine, due to hemoglobinuria. 

The peripheral smear shows characteristic "bite cells" or degmacytes or blister cells. In G6PD deficiency uncontrolled oxidative stress causes hemoglobin to denature and form Heinz bodies. Bite cells result from the removal of Heinz bodies by macrophages in the spleen.

Cotrimoxazole contains sulfamethoxazole which triggers a hemolytic reaction in people with G6PD deficiency.

questions.text: A physiologist studies about the sensor which detects elevated sodium and decreases the glomerular filtration rate. In the given image of the juxtaglomerular apparatus, which of the following structures acts as this sensor?
questions.solution:
The structure marked '1' is the macula densa cells in the distal convoluted tubule and they are involved in detecting elevated sodium levels and thereby decreasing the glomerular filtration rate

The given image constitutes the juxtaglomerular apparatus and has the following parts:

  • Macula densa: Specialized cells at the start of Distal Convoluted Tubule form the macula densa. They detect sodium and chloride concentrations of the fluid in the tubule (Chemoreceptor). In response to elevated sodium and chloride, the macula densa cells trigger the contraction of the afferent arteriole, reducing the flow of blood to the glomerulus and the glomerular filtration rate. This happens as follows: When there is increased sodium, there is increased sodium-potassium ATPase activity which leads to increased ATP hydrolysis causing more adenosine formation. The adenosine receptors on the macula densa cells stimulate it to release more calcium, so that there is vasoconstriction of the afferent arteriole, thereby decreasing the GFR.
  • Granular cells/JG cells: Modified smooth muscle cells of the afferent arteriole, they secrete renin. Fall in pressure in afferent arteriole stimulates renin release (mechanoreceptor), which, in turn, increases blood pressure. They are denoted by '2' in the given image.
  • Lacis cells: Extraglomerular mesangial cells situated between afferent and efferent arteriole. They are marked as '3' in the given image.
    The structure marked as '4' in the given image is the proximal tubular cell. It is involved in the process of glomerulotubular balance. 

When an increase in the GFR occurs, there is a consequential increase in the reabsorption of the solutes and water in the proximal convoluted tubule. This process is called the glomerulotubular balance and it keeps the percentage of the reabsorbed solutes at constant levels.

questions.text: Which statistical test would you choose to compare the blood sugar levels across three patient groups receiving different treatments: Glimiperide (Group 1), Dapagliflozin (Group 2), and Vildagliptin (Group 3)?
questions.solution:
Analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to compare the means among three or more groups. 

The t-test and analysis of variance (ANOVA) are statistical methods used in the testing of hypotheses for the comparison between the means of groups.

The independent t test, also called unpaired t test, is a statistical test that determines whether there is a statistically significant difference between the means in two unrelated (independent) groups. A comparison between BMI in males and in females of a population is an example of a case where unpaired t-test is used.

The paired t-test compares paired data or pre-intervention and post-intervention data of the same group. If a study were to compare BP in a group of patients before and after treatment, then paired t-test would be used.

The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric (non-numeric) test, and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data. In the given study, if CRP levels in each group were categorized as high and low and the three groups then compared, then the Chi-square test would be used.

Related Pearl: Tests of Significance

How to choose which test to use?

  • See the variable. Are the variables quantitative or qualitative?
    • If the variables are qualitative (nominal), then Chi square test is used.
    • If the variables are quantitative, then see whether 2 groups are being tested, or more than 2 groups.
      • If 2 groups are being tested, then T tests are used. In that, if the same group is tested before and after, paired T test is used. Otherwise, unpaired T test is used.
      • If more than 2 groups are being tested, then use ANOVA.

The tests:

1. T Tests

  • Unpaired t tests
    • Also known as the student’s t test, independent t test, two-samples t test.
    • It's the most commonly used t test and it tests the difference between two groups (the means of 2 groups) independent of each other and indicates how significant the differences are.
  • Paired t tests
    • "Pairs before marriage are not the same after!"
    • So remember paired test is mainly used in comparison of a before and after scenario 
    • Also known as correlated t test, dependent samples t test.
    • It is mainly used on dependent samples For example, the cholesterol level of a person before and after using a specific drug.
    • It can also be used when you put the same condition under test using different items or things. For example, same crash safety tests for different cars.
  • T scores 
    • The t score is referred to as the ratio of the difference between two groups and the difference within the groups.
    • The smaller the t score, the more similarity there is between two groups and vice versa.

 

2. Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)

  • The analysis of variance test (ANOVA) is used to test the difference between two or usually more than two groups (means) and here the inferences are made by analyzing the variances.

 

3. Chi-Square Test

  • The Chi-Square test (χ2) is a non-parametric(non-numeric) test and it is used to test hypotheses in relation to nominal scale data or categorical data.
  • It is a test of proportions and associations.
  • A Chi-square distribution is usually positively skewed but it approaches a normal distribution as its degrees of freedom increases.
  • If the frequency of any of the cells of the categorical table is <5, then Fisher’s exact test is used.

questions.text: A 20-year-old female patient presents with the following finding as shown in the image below. On further investigation, she is found to have reduced levels of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. Which of the following disorders is she most likely suffering from?
questions.solution:
With the given clinical scenario and with reduced levels of enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, the patient is most likely suffering from Gilbert syndrome. 

Gilbert syndrome is an autosomal recessive condition characterized by decreased activity of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase, which is responsible for the conjugation of bilirubin. This leads to unconjugated hyperbilirubinemia, that presents as yellowish discolouration of the sclera (icterus/jaundice) as seen in the given image.

Individuals with Gilbert syndrome are usually asymptomatic except for intermittent episodes of jaundice, which usually occurs for the first time during adolescence, due to changes in the concentration of sex hormones. Some patients may have complaints like malaise, fatigue, nausea, anxiety, loss of appetite, and abdominal discomfort. Symptoms are usually precipitated by triggers such as fasting, intercurrent illness, menstruation, and dehydration.

Administration of phenobarbital shows normalisation of the serum bilirubin concentration and hepatic bilirubin clearance.

Gilbert syndrome usually doesn't require any treatment.

Other options:

Option A: Type I Crigler-Najjar syndrome is characterized by a complete deficiency of the enzyme UDP-glucuronosyltransferase. It usually presents as severe congenital jaundice (serum bilirubin levels over 20 mg/dL) and accompanying brain damage.

Options C and D: Dubin Johnson and Rotor syndrome both have elevated conjugated bilirubin in the blood, and are due to defective secretion of conjugated bilirubin into the bile.

questions.text: During a neurological examination of a patient with hand weakness, the physician observes impaired movement in the 1st lumbrical muscle. Which nerve primarily innervates this muscle?
questions.solution:
The median nerve supplies the 1st lumbrical which is marked. 

There are four lumbrical muscles. They originate from the tendons of the flexor digitorum profundus. It passes to the radial side of the corresponding fingers and is inserted into the dorsal digital expansion of the extensor digitorum.

The action of lumbricals is flexion at the metacarpophalangeal joint and extension of interphalangeal joints. 

Lumbricals can be tested only along with interosseous muscle. The examiner will hold the metacarpophalangeal joint of the index finger in hyperextension. Then the patient is asked to extend the proximal interphalangeal joint against resistance. The test is repeated on other fingers as well.

The median nerve innervates the first and second lumbricals. The deep terminal branch of the ulnar nerve innervates the third and the fourth. 

The median nerve is formed by the union of the lateral root (C6, 7) from the lateral cord, and the medial root (C8, T1) from the medial cord.

On the hand, it is seen proximal to the flexor retinaculum and lateral to the tendons of flexor digitorum superficialis. It also lies between the tendons of flexor carpi radialis and palmaris longus.

Its cutaneous supply in hand is as follows: 

  • Lateral 2/3rd of the palm by superficial cutaneous branch
  • Lateral 3½ fingers (palmar aspect and dorsal aspect of nailbeds) by palmar digital nerves

The muscles supplied by the median nerve in the hand are flexor pollicis brevis, abductor pollicis brevis, opponens pollicis, and first dorsal interosseous.

The median nerve sometimes gets compressed under the fibro-osseous tunnel beneath the flexor retinaculum leading to carpal tunnel syndrome. 

Pen test is used to test the median nerve in the hand. It tests the abductor pollicis brevis muscle.  The hand must remain flat with the palm facing upwards. A pen is held above the palm and the patient is asked to touch the pen with his thumb.
